PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its grave concern at the dramatic downturn in the number of new dwellings financed in South Australia since the election of the Tonkin Liberal Government in 1979 as revealed in the Australian Bureau of Statistics Bulletin 'Housing Finance for Owner Occupation, Australia' No. 5609.0 August 1981; and

(1) (a) That in the three months to August 1981 the number of new dwellings financed throughout Australia declined by 9.5 per cent from the same period to August 1979 while in South Australia the decline was 13.2 per cent; and
(b) that in the three months to August 1979 the number of dwellings financed in South Australia was 5,852 as against 5,077 for the corresponding period of 1981; and
(2) the Senate notes that this downturn in loans for new home construction in South Australia indicates very difficult times ahead for home seekers in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. As we are reaching the end of this session, I wonder what explanation will be given for the failure of the Government to bring in legislation to provide for the case of a resident migrant woman seeking citizenship who is presently denied the right to have her children on her citizenship certificate. My second query relates to the uniformity of electoral registration for overseas people which was promised by giving everyone now a permanent resident uniform entitlement, after an obligatory period, to vote in Australia.

—I am not in a position to answer that question from Senator Mulvihill at the moment. I will refer it to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Of course, if the Senate were to rise tomorrow I would get the answer for the Senate before it did so. I will see what I can do to encourage an early answer, if possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REGULATION OF INSURANCE AGENTS AND BROKERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to the fact that even the apostles of deregulation, the members of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, have now reported against sole reliance on self-regulation for insurance agents and brokers and have suggested a system of co-regulation involving co-operative national legislation with industry involvement in its administration. In the light of these views, will the Australian Government and the Treasurer in particular reconsider their announced attitude towards the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill, passed by the Senate last week, and enter into serious discussions on the terms of such legislation with the State governments, the insurance industry and interested members of parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As the Treasurer made clear when introducing the Campbell report, a committee has the report under study. A number of matters will be considered by the Government as a result of further study. I will ask the Treasurer to see that the matter of insurance agents and brokers is one of the matters examined. I am aware that some State governments also have made arrangements to make a very careful study of the Campbell Committee report. I am sure that as a result of their studies they will have views on some of those matters. However, Senator Missen's question will be drawn to the attention of the Treasurer. If the Treasurer wishes to make a response at this stage or a later stage, I will see that Senator Missen is advised.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Has the Government received representation from Actors Equity and the Australian Writers' Guild on the Government's 39 per cent cut in the funding of the Australia Council since 1974? Is the Minister prepared to approach the Prime Minister with a request for a supplementary grant of $1.18m to the Australia Council? Does the Minister now understand that the failure to obtain that supplementary grant will lead to irreparable damage to the entire entertainment industry in this country and a major loss to Australia's culture? Is a major facet of Australia's culture to be sacrificed to save a mere 0.025 per cent of Budget outlays?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe Senator Childs's question is misconceived and inaccurate in its conclusions. I am not aware whether the Australian Writers' Guild or Actors Equity has made approaches to the Government, but I imagine that if they have an interest in this matter they might well have made approaches; they might well have made submissions. I can certainly find that out. The fact is that the Australia Council does a significant job in promoting the arts in Australia; it receives very considerable support from the Government; and, most importantly, it now has a new chairman, a man who is expert in management matters and who has already made his presence felt. Already he is trying to make sure that the Australia Council emerges as an even more efficient and able organisation than it has been over the years.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know whether there has been a request for a further $1.18m, the figure Senator Childs mentioned. Clearly, that is a matter that would be decided in a Budget context. Any further grant for the Australia Council would be a decision for Government to take at the time of formulating a Budget. I am sure that appropriate decisions will be taken at the proper time. In the meantime, I have no doubt that the Australia Council will continue to promote the arts in Australia as it is supposed to do. I am sure that the resources it has will enable it to do this most adequately.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the very successful visit to South Australia made by the Prime Minister earlier this month. In particular, I refer to the discussions the Prime Minister had with the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, and the decision taken that South Australia pay this year an amount of less than $36m to discharge completely the previous Labor Government's indulgent and irresponsible debt of $79m for the South Australian Land Commission. Has the Commonwealth Cabinet confirmed this decision in South Australia's favour, thus putting behind us all the impedimenta of the earlier years which were not of the Liberal Government's making?

—There is in the Federal Budget a figure of $36m for payment for land. That figure was reached after a series of quite independent valuations. Although the land is worth more, it would need to be put on the market for a number of years to get that yield. Both sides agreed that the figure was an accurate and a fair valuation. There have been discussions on the period of payment. It has now been decided that $36m will be paid in this way: One payment now and two equal payments, one next year and one the year after. A payment of $25m or $26m will be made now and, from memory, two equal payments will be made over the next two years. The essential situation is that--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Is the Leader of the Government in conformity with Standing Orders in giving an answer to this question when I already have on the Notice Paper a notice of motion, No. 57, to bring this matter on for debate in this chamber? Is he infringing the Standing Orders by debating the matter now? Why can we not have a debate on this matter?

—There is no point of order. The Leader of the Government is answering a question. He would be aware of the Standing Orders of this chamber and no doubt has taken that matter into consideration. I again call the Leader of the Government, Senator Carrick.

—All I want to say is that there has been an amicable and equitable resolution of the matter. The South Australian Government has acknowledged that the Commonwealth's offer is fair, and that will conclude the amount that is shown in the Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, is further to the question asked by Senator Chipp last Tuesday. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the report of the Defence Sub-committee of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence tabled yesterday which specifically states that three United States bases in Australia are likely to be on the list of Soviet nuclear targets? I refer, of course, to North West Cape in Western Australia, Pine Gap near Alice Springs and Nurrungar near Woomera in South Australia. I ask the Minister also whether he noted the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald which states:

QUESTION.PARA: claims that if the facilities did not exist, Australia would not present any worthwhile nuclear targets.
The report makes nonsense of repeated Defence Department statements in the past that Australia is at nuclear risk whether the United States has facilities here or not.

Has the Minister noted also the Committee's comment that, while urban areas would not be seriously affected by a Soviet attack, 'airborne debris would gradually fall over the southern hemisphere'? In the light of this information, what comment has the Minister to make about the report and what action does the Government intend to take to safeguard Australia and its people and preferably the rest of the southern hemisphere from the effects of such airborne debris in the wake of a nuclear attack?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I responded to Senator Chipp's question the other day I said that the best way to safeguard the Australian people from airborne debris was to stop nuclear war entirely. I pointed out the physical situation known as the cosmic mix. Wherever in the world atomic missiles are exploded, physically there is a mix. Whereas here in Canberra at this moment from natural causes there are something like 102 millirads of exposure, there are an extra two millirads for all the atom bombs that have been exploded in the world. They have been equally mixed up in the cosmic mix.

—Well, Labor Party senators laugh, but the Labor Party was intense when former Senator Murphy took to the World Court the question of the Mururoa Atoll explosive tests and pointed out that wherever the winds might blow the effect of those explosions would be shared equally around the world in the cosmic mix. So in fact what I am saying is in line with the evidence given by the then Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I well remember that Senator Chipp asked me a question. The answer that I gave in effect was that one has two choices-either to have defences to try to obviate war or to have no defences at all. If one is to have defences to obviate war, that is, to provide a sufficient deterrent to safeguard peace, those very defences, whatever they may be-be they installations, armament, armour or troops-will be, of course, potential targets should a potential enemy decide to embark upon war. This is precisely the situation that has always been realised, that everything--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have denied it.

—I remind Senator Robertson, who is now pointing his finger, that Darwin was bombed in World War II. There were no B52s and no deterrent installations at all. Darwin was bombed because the then enemy decided that it had defensive installations and, therefore, it was vulnerable to attack. One has simply to determine what are the most effective defensive mechanisms by way of installations and defence armament to prevent war. If those installations are interesting targets should there be a war, one must take those risks.

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I draw your attention to the fact that while the Minister is making his speech he is taking up Question Time. If he wants to make a speech I suggest that he do it in general debate.

—Order! I will respond to Senator Keeffe's point of order. There is absolutely no point of order. There have been interjections in response to the Minister's answer. He has responded to some of those interjections. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—Mr President, I was asked a lengthy question in a number of parts. The fact of the matter is that a serious question demands a serious answer. My answer is that I have not read the report itself. I have read newspaper reports on this situation. I repeat that wherever one sets up in peace time installations aimed at deterring war, in the horrible event of war, whether those installations are of the type at Pine Gap or at military camps, they are likely to be the targets of retaliation, as Darwin indicated in the past.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am appalled at the Minister's perception of airborne debris as some vague thing which is in the atmosphere. We are talking about fall-out from nuclear explosions. In the light of this clear official statement that we are subject in this country to the likelihood of nuclear attack and fall-out across the whole of the southern hemisphere, is the Minister now saying to me that the Government has no consideration whatsoever of even the most limited forms of civil defence which might begin to protect the people of this country?

—Mr President, as you will have observed the supplementary question bore no relation to the initial question. I related my remarks to the question about debris and pointed out that nuclear debris and fall-out, because of the phenomenon of cosmic mix, occurs world-wide and that there can be no nuclear free zones in a world in which nuclear weapons are exploded. One should do everything that one can to deter any kind of war, either conventional or nuclear. It is in the best judgment of the free world that installations such as those at Exmouth Gulf and Pine Gap are essential to provide the best estimate of the maintenance of peace and the deterrence of war. We could put down all our defensive mechanisms and become totally exposed. That would not prevent us from the debris of nuclear war. It would probably aggravate the opportunities for such a war.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the recent decision of the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation to picket schools when non-striking teachers are teaching, can the Minister assure the Senate that adequate police protection will be available for children and their parents running the gauntlet of these picket lines? Also, will the non-striking teachers be protected?

—I think that all Australians would be very concerned if school children had to run the gauntlet of unionists in order to get to school to receive their education. I think there would be very few people who would regard this as anything short of disgraceful. I sincerely hope that the Australian Capital Territory--
—Bring out the Army; bring out the trucks.

—I notice that there is some yahooing from the other side. Let me say that for little children to have to cross a picket line in order to get their education reflects no credit upon anyone who would want to man that picket line. There are plenty of other ways which people have open to them to pursue their quite legitimate grievances in the industrial area. They do not extend to putting up a picket line in front of a school. I think all honourable senators would want to endorse Senator Reid's concern that children in the Australian Capital Territory should not have to be put to this kind of test. I will have to find out the present situation in this dispute but I share Senator Reid's concern that this kind of situation should even be in prospect in the Australian Capital Territory.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF ALL FORMS OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and relates to ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Is the Attorney-General aware that the Australian Labor Party Opposition has introduced in the Western Australian Parliament a Bill for an equal opportunity Act? Would Australian ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women be hastened if, by some miracle, the Court Government were prepared to support the Bill? Is the Attorney-General prepared to use his good offices to persuade the Western Australian Government either to support the Opposition Bill or to introduce a Government Bill along the same lines?

—As I have told the Senate on more than one occasion, the question of ratification of the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women is, and has been for some time, under consideration by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. It is fair to say that reasonable progress is being made in considering the problems involved. I am aware that a Bill has been introduced into the Western Australian Parliament by the Labor Opposition. I doubt whether the introduction of that legislation will help matters one way or the other as far as the deliberations of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General are concerned. I will simply press on with the course that I have already taken on this matter. I have every confidence that we will achieve terms on which Australia can ratify this convention, in the same way as we had success in obtaining agreement on the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

—My question also is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to a recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that a system of automatic declassification of national security documents be instituted by the Government. I ask: Does such a system work very well in the United States of America and would it eliminate the accumulation of vast masses of obsolete, grossly overclassified material, with the attendant problems of secure storage, protection and, perhaps most importantly, the loss of credibility of national security classifications? Did the Minister say more than a year ago that the matter was under study by the Government? I ask him what progress has been made.

—It is certainly the case that in the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the Freedom of Information Bill I indicated that a study would be made of this particular recommendation. I have made some inquiries; the study that was promised has not yet been completed. I propose, as soon as I have some time to do so, to have further discussions with the officers of my Department who are conducting the study to see just how much progress has been made and what tentative conclusions they may have come to. I am, of course, aware of the declassification system operating in the United States but I am not in a position to give any opinion at this stage on an evaluation of that system. As I have said, we are well aware of the system and it is a very interesting one. I am concerned to learn more about it and to be able to make an evaluation of it as Senator Hamer has suggested.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is it true that Telecom Australia installs PABX equipment manufactured by three companies, Siemens Industries Ltd, Philips Industries Holdings Ltd and NEC Australia Pty Ltd? Did Telecom undertake last week an advertising campaign directed at government and semi-government instrumentalities, offering to help them in the selection and installation of PABX systems? Is it a fact that the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, intervened and ordered Telecom to stop its advertising campaign? Was this the Minister's reaction to pressure applied by manufacturers whose PABX equipment is not installed by Telecom? Alternatively, does it represent the spirit of competition that the Minister for Communications and other members of the Fraser Government continue to espouse as being appropriate for government instrumentalities such as Telecom?

—The information which I have on this matter is rather limited, but I will give Senator Button what I have and he can indicate whether he wants further information. I understand that the PABX market is segmented so that Commonwealth Government departments are supplied by Telecom, the private market is supplied by private companies and the State, local government and semi-government authorities market is open to competition between Telecom and private companies. This is the way in which the market has been segmented. The advertising campaign to which the honourable senator referred was aimed at meeting Telecom's PABX sales program in parts of the market for which it has responsibility. It was not trying to encroach upon the private sector's share of the market. However, some complaints were received from the private sector. In view of those complaints, a decision was taken that the advertising campaign should cease.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister kindly offered to obtain further information. In view of his answer, I would be very grateful for any further information he can give as to how the Minister justifies interference with Telecom's capacity to advertise in an area in which it has, by arrangement, almost exclusive coverage of the market.

—I do not believe that anything I said in my answer indicated that it was a Government decision that the advertising campaign should cease. I will certainly find out from my colleague how the decision was taken and try to answer the extra questions that the honourable senator has asked.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In hindsight, could the fact that small business received so little consideration in the recommendations of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System be due to the composition of the membership of the inquiry being representative merely of big business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the Campbell Committee believes that it has conducted a very wide-ranging examination of the financial structure of this country. I do not think that an assumption such as that implied in Senator Watson's question should be made. The recommendations of the Campbell inquiry are very wide-ranging. Perhaps Senator Watson feels that small business should have been given greater prominence in some of the recommendations, but I think it is quite unfair to infer that the composition of the membership of the Committee limited, in that way, its examination of the financial structure or limited the recommendations that it was prepared to put to the Government. As I have said on a number of occasions, the recommendations of the Committee are under study. I am sure that, arising from that, many matters will need further examination. If there is some gap in the recommendations that have been made, perhaps Senator Watson would like to give us some information on what he would like fed into the examination of the recommendations so that the particular area that he has mentioned can have our further consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELEPHONE SERVICE TO LORD HOWE ISLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications been drawn to articles in newspapers, including the National Times, relating to the upgrading of a telephone service to Lord Howe Island? Is it a fact that the Minister for Communications intervened in relation to the draft capital works program for Telecom Australia to have $1m allocated by Telecom for this service?
—You do not believe what you read in the National Times, do you?

—One day the honourable senator will, no doubt, be a Minister and then he can answer the question. I ask: Is it true that the Minister for Communications intervened in relation to Telecom's capital works program to have $1m allocated by Telecom to this Lord Howe Island service? Was the intervention in the form of a notation in the Minister's well-known handwriting on the side of a letter? Is it also a fact that as a result of that intervention new exchanges for country areas have been deferred? Does the number of country exchanges deferred now amount to a total of 31?

—I will have to find out from the Minister whether he intervened and, if so, in what way. I have some information on the Lord Howe Island exchange. It does not cover that point and I think it is better that I refer the question to the Minister.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to a recent decision of the Government with regard to income tax zone allowances. I remind her that the Northern Territory Government computed a cost of living disadvantage in Darwin of $2,600 per adult per year. On that basis both major Northern Territory parties in their submissions to the Cox Public Inquiry into Income Tax Zone Allowances supported the demand for an annual rebate of $2,500. Mr George Slater, a member of the inquiry, in his minority report recommended a restructuring of the zones, with Darwin and Mount Isa to be incorporated in a new zone B with an annual rebate of $1,500. Given that Mr Slater's recommendation was the only one to approach the recommendations of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Western Mining Corporation and the governments of Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania, and given the fact that Mr Slater expressed serious doubts about the conduct of the inquiry concerning unjustifiable time constraints, will the Minister undertake to ask the Treasurer to reconvene the inquiry to reconsider the zone allowance for these severely disadvantaged Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I certainly will refer to the Treasurer the request to look further at the zone allowances, but the recommendations that came forward to the Government did receive a lot of consideration. There certainly was a minority report which also received consideration. In looking at the zone allowances it is always difficult to remove benefits that have once been enjoyed and at the same time give some recognition to the difficulties of people living in the more remote areas of Australia. We felt that the final outcome was satisfactory from the Government's viewpoint, taking into account the many difficulties and sometimes inequities that can result from it. However, I would have no hesitation in referring Senator Robertson's comments to the Treasurer. If he sees fit to review the recommendations again, I feel sure that that would be done at an appropriate time, although I would not expect that he would feel that it is appropriate immediately to do so, the Government having given as much consideration to this matter as it has in the recent past.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMUNITY YOUTH SUPPORT SCHEME: BOX HILL

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of urgency, will the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs seek an answer as to the future of the Box Hill Community Youth Support Scheme group currently suspended and threatened with termination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the circumstances of the Box Hill group. I am aware that the Minister is receiving many representations about the CYSS program. He is hoping to have, I think early next year, a final report on that program and to look at the future of it then. If there is some problem of suspension in Box Hill, Victoria, I will ask that that matter receive his urgent attention and see what action he considers it as appropriate to take.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DISABLED PERSONS: ACCESS TO AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY IN WASHINGTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, unless the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs thinks it more appropriate that she answer it. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Embassy in Washington has no ready access for disabled people such as those in wheelchairs? Is it one of the few public buildings in that city not so accessible? Does the Government have a policy on making buildings accessible to the disabled and does this policy apply to buildings overseas? Will the Government, in this International Year of Disabled Persons, take some action to remedy the position?

—I am aware that early this year the Government undertook a program to increase the access to public buildings in this country for disabled people. I think I can say to Senator Coates that there is a policy to try to make sure that there is access to public buildings for all people. That includes special means of access for those who are disabled. If the Australian Embassy building in Washington has no such access-Senator Coates advises that that is the case-I think it is appropriate that that matter be drawn to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services so that it can be investigated. Clearly, if there is no such access it would be desirable that it be provided.

—My question is directed to Senator Carrick in his capacity as Minister for National Development and Energy but possibly also in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. As a member of the universal church I do not know whether I am one of the cosmic micks to whom he referred earlier. Nevertheless, I ask: Is it a fact that the International Bauxite Association Council had a meeting in Australia in the first week of November? Is it a fact that that Council recommended that, in view of the expected soft market situation for 1982, the price for base grade bauxite should, for reference purposes, be set at 2 per cent of the average metal market list price for primary aluminium and soon for alumina? Do exporters of Australian bauxite and alumina regard themselves as bound by those recommendations? Whether the answer is yes or no, will the Australian Government be using its export controls over bauxite and alumina to ensure that the recommendations of the International Bauxite Association are adhered to in order to further the North-South dialogue to which this Prime Minister is committed, in the interests of those developing countries, particularly Jamaica, which would be well served by a strengthening of the cartel-like operations of the International Bauxite Association?

—It is a fact that there was a meeting of the International Bauxite Association Council in Canberra early in November. Primarily this is a matter for the Minister for Trade and Resources. I was, in fact, invited to that meeting but could not attend. So I do not have first hand information on that matter, but I will seek that information. It is a fact that bauxite, alumina and aluminium prices the world over are seriously depressed. I think recently, on the London metal market, the price of aluminium was something in the order of $936, which is some hundreds of dollars lower than it has been in the past. That has been due to the recession brought about by high oil pricing and the consumption of foreign exchange by countries buying oil rather than trading otherwise. As the remainder of the honourable senator's questions relate specifically to the portfolio of my colleague, the Minister for Trade and Resources, I will bring them to his attention and seek an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Has the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs carried out a close monitoring of the transfers of quotas in the clothing import section? Has there been any significant change in the groups of holders such as manufacturers, agents, wholesalers and retailers? Is this according to the plan that the Department had in mind? Is it seen to produce any effect in the market place? Has the Department any plans to accelerate or to retard that position?

—I think honourable senators would know full well the great deal of interest which Senator Archer has in this matter of textile quotas and indeed his progressive attitude as President of the Australian Clothing Export Council. I indicate that in the general thrust of his question a number of details are required. I need to refer that matter to the Minister to obtain a detailed reply for him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL OFFICER FOR NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services: Is the position of Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales shortly to become vacant as a result of pressure by the Australian Government? Is it proposed to appoint to that position the current Australian Electoral Officer for Queensland who was a central figure in the McGregor inquiry into alleged malpractices in the 1977 redistribution in Queensland which resulted in the sacking of that officer's Minister? Will the Government give an undertaking that the position, should it become vacant, will be advertised and therefore open to all other applicants within and outside the Public Service, as was the case in respect of the recent vacancy in the position of Australian Electoral Officer for Western Australia?

—I would find it very difficult to believe that pressure was exerted by the Australian Government on any electoral officer to give up his position. I will have to find out whether the Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales-I take it the honourable senator is talking about Mr White-is intending to give up his post. I know nothing of this matter. I believe that if any officer resigned the normal procedures would be followed in filling that position, should there be a vacancy which required a replacement officer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to a report in this morning's Australian newspaper that in Melbourne on Sunday the Prime Minister will launch a national appeal to raise aid for Poland. Will the Prime Minister use the occasion to announce Government financial support for food aid to Poland, as suggested in the Australian Labor Party's matter of public importance on Tuesday, or will he ignore the real plight of the Polish people and continue to grandstand on this issue?

—I cannot imagine that an appeal to the people of Australia to provide money for assistance to Poland could be taken as grandstanding. I would think that the average person in Australia, and certainly the Association of Free Poles in Australia which has asked that this appeal be launched, would take unkindly any suggestion that what is happening is grandstanding. Basically the nature of the aid to Poland is the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As to the nature of the aid, I will refer the question to him and seek any further response.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to an article in today's Australian in relation to the report by consultants to the Department of Industrial Relations which is said to have expressed concern at the number of amendments-some 25 in number-made to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since 1965. Is the Minister satisfied that there is sufficient certainty in our system of industrial law? Is the Minister satisfied that the legislative framework is both coherent and cohesive?

—I will have to refer that question to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, in order to get a complete answer to it, as I think it is the Minister's opinion that is sought rather than my own. However, I think I can presume to indicate on his behalf that he must have some concern of the sort which is indicated by the honourable senator in his question, because earlier this year the Minister did engage part time consultants to undertake a review of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The terms of reference for the review were to make recommendations as to how the provisions of the Act and Regulations can best be simplified and clarified and to formulate proposals for their integration into a more coherent and cohesive legislative framework. I do not quote the terms of reference in total, but I think they are the words that are relevant to the point raised by the honourable senator. I think that reference indicates that the Minister does have concern about the state of the Act and about whether it can be simplified and clarified, but I will refer the question to him to see whether he wants to give a more extensive and detailed reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I preface my question by referring to the Press release issued by the Minister in conjunction with the Minister for Health which set out that a pilot study will be undertaken of 200 personnel who were involved in the United Kingdom atomic tests program at Monte Bello, Emu and Maralinga in the 1950s. Will the pilot study be dealing exclusively with those personnel who are still alive, as seems to be implied in the Press release, or will the health records of deceased personnel also be included?

—The pilot study has been designed scientifically and completely objectively. Let me try to make the position perfectly clear. As far as we know, approximately 15,000 persons were at the Maralinga, Emu or Monte Bello Islands sites during that time. It is my aim and the aim of my Department to locate all those persons who can be located, or the relatives of the deceased, to examine the cause of death and to get as effective a study of all persons as we can. I have every reason to believe that in the end we will have something between 10,000 and 12,000 of the 15,000, which will be a massive job. We have sought and are obtaining from both our own records and the British records the health records of all these people so that the study will go out not to people we know to be alive but to a cross-section of people. DEBATE.TITLE: URANIUM MINING LAWS IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

My remarks on this matter will be fairly brief because I will be speaking not to the report itself, which I have not read, but to the topic. I apologise for not speaking more fully but the honourable senator who was to have moved the motion to take note of this paper is not here today, otherwise the report would have been given the treatment which it merits. I would like to make a few brief comments before seeking leave to continue my remarks. I remind honourable senators of the comments of the consultants on clause 2 (1) of the terms of reference, as set out on page 4 of their report. They state:
In our view, the contents of that sub-clause make it desirable that we indicate against any recommendation where it relates to any of the following:
administrative overlap or duplication
legal overlapping or duplication
inherent legal problems
policy
incidental matters.
The reason the report was commissioned is dealt with on page 5, which reads:

In the first report of the Uranium Advisory Council in 1979, reference was made to 'the proliferation of relevant laws and regulations at a Federal and State level, with the attendant prospect of conflict and confusion'.

It is understandable that in the interim period as the Northern Territory moves from control by Canberra through to its own self-government there will be some sort of overlap and some sort of duplication. It is understandable also, I feel, that the Northern Territory Government wishes to control all the activities in the Northern Territory. To make a comparison by looking back to Aboriginal land rights and to the wish of the Northern Territory to control national parks, in both of these areas the Federal Government has indicated that it has certain wishes and the Northern Territory Government has come out quite strongly to say that the Federal Government has no responsibility in this area; it should be the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. There are many people in the Northern Territory who would support the Federal view that there is room for a Federal presence at present. They fear control by the Northern Territory Government at present on two grounds, I think: Basically because of its association with big business and that decisions will be made because of that association; and they also fear the 'develop at all costs' syndrome.

Again I compare the situation of uranium mining with that of land rights. There was a clear decision by the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory that the Federal Government should retain responsibility. That was indicated clearly when the Joint Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights in the Northern Territory went around examining the matter. It has been indicated clearly by statements that the Aboriginal people have since made through their Northern Land Council, the Central Land Council and other bodies. I believe that the report we are looking at today on uranium, the matter of land rights and the matter of the Kakadu National Park are all interwoven.

There is no doubt at all that we do need clear laws. We can see from the report that there is a multiplicity of laws. It is quite clear that the group which undertook the inquiry has defined a number of areas in which there is duplication and overlap. We also need to define very clearly the responsibility for the setting up of the laws, the establishment of the laws and then their implementation. I come down clearly at this stage on the side of the Federal Government. I believe that the development of the national park, the problems associated with land rights and the situation concerning uranium, at this stage anyway, ought to be the responsibility of the Federal Government. I do not think I need go into the arguments on this. We can canvass these at another time.

Nevertheless, I am very pleased to see that this report has been brought down. I am happy to be able to state the point of view from this side of the chamber that it should be a Federal responsibility. I believe that this view is shared by the majority of the people in the Northern Territory. I look forward to giving greater study to the report and at a later stage making a more detailed comment. Because of that, I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

As a South Australian any report on tourism is of interest to me, and the annual reports of the Australian Tourist Commission are of particular interest. I recall in 1978, when I was first in this place, making some comments on the 1977-78 annual report. I have a horrible feeling that my comments then will be seen to be very similar to my comments now. In the letter of the Chairman of the Commission to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) there are a number of interesting statements. The first is that the Government provided a sum of $8.6m in order that the Australian Tourist Commission could arrange a program of overseas marketing for 1980-81 and that that marketing program was essentially successful in that it maintained the same real level of marketing activities as had occurred with the $8m Budget for 1979-80. The letter states:
The high growth rate in visitor arrivals stemming from 1977-78 continued in 1980. But for 1980 short-term visitors totalled 904,558-up 14% on the previous year.

The report provides a number of charts and figures which are particularly interesting to those of us who live in non-eastern States. Visitor figures are listed on page 8 of the report. As I have said, over the last three or four years the ATC has been particularly successful in increasing the number of overseas visitors to Australia. However, if we turn to a table on page 22 of the report we find that the length of stay of visitors in 1980 was, in the majority of cases, less than three weeks. Given the size of Australia, I suggest that all that would do is give those visitors-the majority of the 900,000-odd people who visit this country-the opportunity to visit only the eastern States; that is, they would fly into one of the international airports on the eastern seaboard, work their way up or down that seaboard and then disappear across to Christchurch or go back home, leaving the greatest part of Australia unexplored by them. This is borne out by the fact that only $331,247 of the $8.6m that the Government provides to the ATC is devoted to domestic tourism promotions. This amount is hardly substantial enough to divert any of those 900,000 people to the major part of the country and encourage them to go further into Australia than just Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. Their problems are made worse by the fact that, typically, the Commission has offices only in Sydney and Melbourne, which gives the other capital cities in Australia very little opportunity to press for increased marketing of their States.

I suggested in 1978 that we should go back to the position that obtained in 1974 when the Australian Labor Party was in government and domestic tourism marketing was a substantial part of the role of the Australian Tourist Commission. It is essential for the non-eastern States that the Australian Tourist Commission takes a much larger role in marketing domestic tourism-that, of course, would require an increase in funding-or that a domestic tourist commission be established. Frankly, I would prefer the latter. At the moment tourist facilities in Australia are distributed almost randomly around the country; certainly, they are scattered around the country. No attempt of a serious sort appears to have been made by the Federal and State governments and industries to co-ordinate visitors in this country and the travel of those visitors across the country.

Certainly, in the annual report the Australian Tourist Commission points out that it is funding a visitor travel program which incorporates industry input. It seems to me that a domestic tourist commission would be in a far better position, having domestic tourism as its main, in fact only role, to co-ordinate tourism with the States and industry. In fact, I suggest as a start that it could well consider introducing an air travel package of the sort that applies already in most overseas countries. Visitors who come to this country would then pay a small amount of money which would entitle them to travel anywhere in the country for a specified period. The revoltingly high air fares that affect this country-particularly those applicable between Perth and Adelaide-are an extremely inhibiting factor for any overseas visitor who intends travelling across the country rather than simply staying in Brisbane, Melbourne or Sydney.

It would not hurt either if a domestic tourist commission set up, it is hoped by this Government, could suggest the upgrading of regional airports in Australia so that high tourist orientated areas such as the south-east of South Australia had something to offer people immediately they came into the area. This report contains extracts from the annual report of the Australian Postal Commission. In a curious way this report from Australia Post might be regarded as a success for the Fraser Government because, for a government with a stated commitment to downgrading Australia's public enterprises, it must come as something of a triumph for government policy to learn that Australia Post, one of Australia's biggest public enterprises, has recorded its first loss since its creation as a commission. The loss for Australia Post in this year was $12.7m. In fact, Australia Post has always sought to operate at close to break-even point. Last year the Commission made an operating surplus of $11.7m. As the report notes, if those figures were taken into account and averaged out over the two years 1979-80 and 1980-81 Australia Post would have broken even.

Unfortunately, Australia Post cannot offset this year's loss against last year's gain because last year the Government took Australia Post's profits from it to repay a loan. Australia Post had intended to continue to pay interest on that loan because, like a number of other public enterprises under attack from this Government, it has been starved of capital. Not only is the Government winding down the availability of credit for Government enterprises such as Telecom Australia and infrastructure programs, but also it is taking money away from such instrumentalities when they are least able to afford it. To add insult to injury, the Commonwealth has raised interest repayments on outstanding loans from the Commonwealth thus starving Australia Post for capital even further. This attitude to the interest repayments of Australia Post is in stark contrast, of course, to the fixed term loans arranged for National Country Party Ministers such as Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon. The result for Australia Post is that it is forced to abandon substantial elements of its capital works program or, alternatively, to finance those elements by increasing charges. This is an issue which Senator Townley is diligent in pursuit of but apparently he is in ignorance of the reasons for the possible increase in charges about which he talks.

Australia Post has already increased its charges. In July, standard charges rose by 9 per cent. Priority paid charges grew by 43 per cent. Registered publication rates rose by an average of 23 per cent this year. Private box levies have increased by 20 per cent. Christmas card postage will rise by 20 per cent. This report from Australia Post makes it quite clear that further rises are inevitable in the near future as a result of Fraser Government policies. There is no other explanation of rises further to those which the Commission might normally seek. In addition, as I pointed out, Australia Post is being forced to run down its capital development. The effect of Australia Post's running down its capital development is two-fold. Firstly, Australia Post, like Telecom and other statutory authorities, redirects the profits it generates from city postal routes towards the less profitable areas in the country. Any running down of internal financing directly prejudices country areas because the funds are simply unavailable to cross-subsidise country deliveries.

The resultant winding down of country services is already in evidence. It is a matter in respect of which I thought the National Country Party might have had some interest. Indeed, some concern was expressed at the last conference of the National Country Party, held a week or so ago, when for the first time delegates to a National Country Party conference seemed to be aware that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), far from being one of their leaders, might be just pulling their noses. It is important that that issue be brought more and more into the minds of people in the non-metropolitan regions of Australia because that process is going on and on under the administration of the present Government.

I said that it would mean the end, inevitably, of the level of cross subsidy which Australia Post now provides. But the other danger of reduced internal finance is that programs which will cost more in the short term but which will contribute to efficiency in the long term just cannot go ahead. What we are seeing in this is the classic political trade off which the Fraser Government continually makes whereby, for short term political or ideological gain, something is done which will prejudice the country in the long term. This is a Government whose view of the long term extends no further than the next election. That is a tragedy for organisations such as Australia Post and its clients, the people of Australia. What better example of this is there than the termination of Australia Post Courier services. The annual report of Australia Post states this about its Courier Service:
During the year Australia Post Courier achieved further business growth and maintained its position in the highly competitive courier market.
The Courier network was further expanded during 1980-81 to encompass a total of 41 centres, including bases in all State capitals, Canberra, Darwin, Gold Coast, Launceston, Newcastle and Wollongong.
At its peak in May there were 333 vehicles in the Courier fleet and 286 Courier drivers.
Following the decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions,-
That is the razor gang-
Australia Post Courier was abolished on 30 June 1981.

That is a report of the Commission drawing attention to the profitability and success of the Australia Post Courier service and a decision, presumably based on dislike of success in government instrumentalities, to abolish that Courier service. That decision was made in April of this year and became effective on 30 June 1981. The position is that, as with Videotex and a number of other communications decisions, completely irrational decisions are made, based on ideology and the need to do favours to particular sections of the business community. Mr Sinclair prevented the implementation of an Australia Post decision which would have meant that in a few years millions of dollars could have been ploughed back into country postal services in Australia. The abolition of the Courier service is just an example of that sort of decision. The report talks of:
. . . the uncertain effects on its finances of changes in its operations, following the decisions of the Government as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

It is talking about the chaos created by ad hoc razor gang decisions handed down from on high. All these things affect the efficiency of Australia Post. As I said, the National Country Party conference expressed its concern at a number of these decisions. Even the National Country Party conference is beginning to wake up to the fact that this Government, day by day, is making decisions in relation to Australian Government instrumentalities which are damaging to the interests of country dwellers. The Federal Government is ushering in a new era of public administration in Australia whereby public investment is shunned and private investment is imagined to be uniquely productive. The Government is bringing that approach to Australia Post, Telecom Australia, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and other public instrumentalities, all of which provide extraordinarily good services for non-metropolitan dwellers throughout Australia. The results of these actions will be to push up charges and to depress the standards of service, particularly in the country. In the meantime, the Government continues to talk. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

I hope that the Government, in its wisdom, brings in some very strict regulations to prevent foreign ownership of Australia's best agricultural land. Although we have very extensive trading arrangements with Japan, no Australian could go to Japan and buy land in that country. I doubt whether he could go to any other country and buy land. Yet because of the strength of the dollar, and the profits some people expect to make backed by the Government, the Goverment allows foreign people to come to this country and buy some of our best agricultural land. I am very pleased that this matter has been discussed at the meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. I look forward to very strict guidelines being introduced which will place strictures on those people buying land in Australia, particularly in the south-east portion of the State in which I live. As I said, concern has been expressed to me, through the clerk of the Council, Mr Johnson, that some of the best land in that area could fall into the hands of foreign owners.

The other matter I wish to mention and to which reference is also made in this report, is the discussion which was held on the export of live sheep from Australia. This concerns many people, particularly from the cruelty angle. That is the angle to which I will refer today. I was very interested to see in the House of Representatives Hansard of Tuesday of this week an answer given by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to a question asked by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) which related to the deaths of sheep on the ship Persia during a trip from Australia to Egypt in September 1981. That is only several months ago. Mr Nixon said that on that particular trip, 8,764 sheep perished. He went on to state:

The Persia completed loading of 49,500 sheep on 1 September 1981. On 4 September the ventilation system was out of action for 35 minutes and 266 sheep died. On 8 September the ventilation system was out of action for 5 3/4 hours and 1,003 sheep died. Both periods of non ventilation were caused by a breakdown in the electrical switching system.

Following these two ventilation failures the main engines had to be run at reduced capacity due to a crack developing in a cylinder head liner. This resulted in a reduction in production of drinking water. The ship altered course and called at Aden to take on additional water. There were 6,028 deaths attributable to this water shortage.
The other 1,495 deaths were due to other miscellaneous causes.

I think it is a cause for very great concern that we are allowing live sheep to be exported from this country when in one shipment 8,764 of those animals perished. Most Australians have a great concern for the welfare of not only the human race but also dumb animals. Some of these ships are like great floating hotels. They are passenger ships which have been converted to live sheep carrying vessels. It is a disgrace that this is allowed to happen. This is something which the Opposition will be pursuing to see that the Government brings in some very strict regulations. I had to raise the matter here some time ago about the cruelty which is inflicted on live horses being shipped to Japan, but that is another matter. We do have some regulations insofar as shipping goes, but my understanding is that no regulations exist for transporting live horses by aircraft to Japan. Recently inspectors from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were not allowed to inspect an aircraft at Tullamarine in order to examine the conditions under which the horses were being transported. We have a lot of matters to look at in this country in the treatment of dumb animals. I hope that the Government will take some cognisance of the complaints that have been made by Senator Mulvihill and myself in this Parliament over a period. It is high time that these practices ceased. There is more to having a very good life than just making money. One has also to give due concern to the ill treatment of animals.

The other matter to which I will refer briefly in the time that is available to me is that portion of the report which relates to the egg industry marketing arrangements. I notice that one matter which came up for discussion-it was proposed by the Victorian Government-concerned an increase from 20 to 1,000 in the size of hen flocks which are exempted from the provision of the Poultry Industry Levy Act 1965-79. I am very pleased that the Council was advised by the representatives from Victoria that the Victorian industry did not support that proposal. I am sure that the industry Australia-wide would not support that proposal. The limit of 20 hens is put there for a very good purpose. It is to allow back yarders or home producers to produce their own eggs without having any detrimental effect on orderly marketing in Australia. Having been a poultry farmer I am well aware that a good poultry farmer, if he looked after his poultry properly, could hope to get a production of 14 dozen eggs a year from any one fowl over the age of six months. Of course, we know that fowls start laying in many cases, long before they are six months old.

I want to confine my remarks to the production of hens which are over six months old. A hen has to be over six months old before the levy is payable. If one multiplies that 14 dozen by 12 one gets a figure of 168 eggs from each hen. If one multiplies that by 20, which is the allowable amount, one gets the figure of 3,360 eggs. If one divides into that figure the number of days in any one year one will come up with a round figure of nine eggs a day that a housholder can produce without having to pay a levy. In my view, that is ample. No householder would use any more than nine eggs a day over the whole year. That is a nominal figure only because, as I have said, eggs would be produced by those laying fowls before they attained the age of six months. That is a matter which I am very pleased was not agreed to by the Australian Agricultural Council.

The other matter which concerns me is that the Agricultural Council has now agreed to lift the hen quota in the Australian Capital Territory from 150,000 to 200,000. I notice that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) sent a telegraphic assurance to the Council that the new quota would be strictly enforced. I hope that we can take some solace from that and that he will enforce it. In the past it has not been enforced in the Australian Capital Territory. There have been many prosecutions against a massive poultry unit in the Australian Capital Territory which is known as Bartters. The fines which were imposed were very minimal. It is stated in the resolutions that the Council agreed that the additional quota be negotiable and that the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia be asked to examine and advise on a mechanism of payment for any additional State or Territory quotas sought in the future. I am concerned now as to whether the extra quota will be handed over to Mr Bartter and that he will increase his monopoly in the Australian Capital Territory. If one does a swift analysis of the figures which I have mentioned one will find that 200,000 hens and a population in the Australian Capital Territory of somewhere around 200,000 more eggs will be produced that can be consumed in the Australian Capital Territory, so the eggs will continue to be exported to Victoria and New South Wales to the detriment of the commercial egg producers in those two States.

In the few seconds that remain, I place on record the appreciation of the poultry industry of Mr Norm Mair, a business manager in South Australia, who gave many years of loyal service to the Australian Egg Board. His services will be missed. As a person who was poultry farming when Mr Mair was with the Hall Sandford company, I can say that he did a magnificent job on behalf of the egg industry in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Despite the Government's best efforts to limit the capacity of its consultative bodies to reflect the needs of the community, its policies have been very sharply criticised by its National Women's Advisory Council. As usual, it has managed to ignore these criticisms and pursue its own agenda to the disadvantage of women and those dependent upon them. This comparatively conservative government-appointed body, which contains senior members of the Government parties, has produced a list of recommendations which show a sensitivity to community needs that is far in excess of the policies and practices of the Government. For example, in a section on women's refuges, its report states:
The Council believes that women's refuges provide essential services to women and their children who are victims of domestic violence.

The Council is most concerned that the new arrangements will force refuges in all States and Territories to compete with established and well-organised lobby groups in the health care system for a share of available funds. The recommendation of the Council on this matter is to urge the Government to reconsider its decision on women's refuges in order to safeguard the financial viability of this service, which is of inestimable value to women and children in crisis. I would like to add to that a very heartfelt 'Amen' from the women of the far-flung and less progressive States of this nation.

Other recommendations include the raising of family allowances for all children, not just for less than a quarter of the children of Australia and the indexing of those allowances; more financial support for full-time careers; and disability allowances to compensate the disabled, both those who work as well as those who do not, for costs incurred. In the International Year of Disabled Persons the Government has done pathetically little for disabled women. The report also recommends special measures for single parents. It puts emphasis on the Office of Child Care and the Children's Services Program as deserving priority in meeting the needs of women. This has been emphasised throughout the recommendations and is clearly seen as vital, yet at present there are proposals which would destroy the essence of this program under the excuse, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) put it yesterday, of rationing resources. Also, the Minister has avoided answering the question whether he will retain the Office of Child Care as a combined policy and subsidy division.

The report contains 91 sensible, reasonable recommendations. However, I must express my concern at the Government's apparent indifference to the issue raised by the Council and its failure to develop an Australian plan of action for the balance of this United Nations Decade for Women. I remind the Senate that the decade has only another four years to go. It is now over a year since the delegation in Copenhagen was forced to vote against the international plan of action on the flimsy excuse of verbal hairsplitting. It is over a year since Australia signed the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women. The Government has not yet produced, let alone endorsed, a plan of action for Australia to show its good will. Instead, appendix 15 of this report contains a recommended plan developed by the National Women's Advisory Council but, as far as I am aware, it has not yet been accepted, endorsed or apparently even been of concern to the Minister. In fact, it is without status.

A quick glance at this Australian program recommended by the Advisory Council shows that it certainly could be of benefit to Australia as a whole and to women in particular. It covers employment, health, education, training, child care, country women, migrant women, lone parents and a range of other issues. These relate to many groups in society who are disadvantaged because of age, youth, physical disabilities or lack of access to paid work. As such, it is important to all Australians that the Government develop its own plan of action and, after appropriate consultations, implement this to the advantage of and justice for all. One part of the report which especially appeals to me is that relating to occupational health and women. I refer to chapter 7. This chapter refers particularly to the lack of data and research on the particular problem of women and work-caused disease and injury. This is a problem of which the National Health and Medical Research Council has been aware since 1978 when the matter was raised by a joint working party on the health of working women. The recommendation from the National Women's Advisory Council on this issue states:

It was agreed that inadequate occupational health statistics disaggregated by sex make it imperative that baseline statistics be collected and analysed to provide uniform nation-wide data on all aspects relating to the occupational health status of women.

Speaking from my own experience as a trade union official over the last few years, I can certainly endorse the need for that information to be collected. The recommendations arising on the subject of the occupational health needs of women were obtained as a result of an excellent seminar conducted by the National Women's Advisory Council in May of this year. It appears to me that this type of seminar has a value way in excess of the actual funds which are spent on setting up such meetings. It is a source of great disappointment that the funding for the National Women's Advisory Council for this current year is somewhat less than it was previously. The cuts in expenditure are at the expense of seminars such as the one to which I referred and publications.

I think the National Women's Advisory Council is one of the government authorities which provides the best value, dollar for dollar, that we are likely to see in this nation. Every dollar is at a special value when we consider the decades of neglect of most of these subjects of particular significance to women and which the Advisory Council deals with so efficiently. I congratulate the Council on this report. I sincerely hope that this council is enabled by the Government to continue to function at the level of excellence to which we have become accustomed.
