SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report was compiled under the auspices of the Commonwealth Department of Health. Whilst I might agree with some of the recommendations that are made in that report let me say at the outset that it does not go far enough. One of the most obvious problems in the development of particular or specific health services, particularly for adolescents, is of course, the limitation of funds which are available. There is no doubt that existing organisations in our community recognise the problems of adolescent health. They also recognise that they are helpless to do anything about the problems because of that limitation of funds about which I have spoken.

We have heard mentioned in this chamber many times, and I have raised this matter many times, about the manner in which Federal funds for family planning associations and the like are effectively cut. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is at the table may feel inclined to say they have not been cut, that the organisations are getting the same amount of money they got last year. I put it to the Senate that in actual fact that is an effective cut of 10 per cent to 12 per cent. If we consider that the previous year the amount was the same then we have to accept that now we are about 20 per cent down on the necessary funds needed to provide family planning associations and other health-related organisations such as women's health care houses with an adequate budget to be able to service the community in a way that they are managing to do today by eking out the existing finances that are available to them.

In Western Australia we are particularly aware of and familiar with the problems of the Family Planning Association of Western Australia. We have the largest State which means that we have the greatest territory to cover. It is only with the assistance and under the auspices of a number of local government councils that we have been able to have family planning association services extended to such places as Esperance and Geraldton. There is a desperate need for family planning associations and related health services in other areas of Western Australia. But, of course, these services are not provided because funds are not available. We know that there is a great need in the community to recognise adolescent health requirements and needs. It is interesting to note that other perhaps more enlightened societies have long recognised the problems of adolescent health. In fact the report at page 3 states:

In the United States adolescent medicine has enjoyed recognition since the early fifties and training programs in the speciality have increased in number with support from Federal funds since that time.

We are 30 years behind in recognising even that there is a problem in the adolescent health area. In looking at this problem the report reiterates four major themes which have already been identified many times by the World Health Organisation working group. Those themes are biological aspects, emotional problems, sexually related behaviour and risk-taking behaviour. We also have to recognise that whilst all of these may apply to adolescent men and women, additional adolescent problems can perhaps be added to the problems of those who happen to be female. This is pointed out in part by the report. The report says, for instance:

At a time when physical appearance and peer comparison are highly prized, delayed sexual development in teenage boys and disparity in breast development in girls are areas of concern of this age group.
Menstrual irregularities are more the norm than the exception in early adolescence and reassurance to anxious young teenage girls by a sympathetic practitioner is the remedy in almost all cases.

Let me just go back from that, while we are talking about the sympathetic practitioner and his reassurance to those young teenage girls, to a comment which was made earlier in the report. Speaking about the situation in the past and relating that to the present, the report states:
When medical care was sought, adolescents tended to fall between paediatrics and adult care.

I put it to the chamber that at the moment they still do. For instance, some years ago my 13-year-old daughter developed severe appendicitis. It was impossible for the medical practitioner to determine whether she should go to the children's hospital, where obviously she would be in a ward with children of a much younger age, or to the Royal Perth Hospital where she would run the possibility of being in a ward with people of a much older age group. The report continues:
True, their particular health and social problems were sometimes exasperating and elusive-
I suggest that the problems were exasperating not only to the medical practitioner but also to the parents who had to try to deal with them.
sometimes requiring a great deal of time to manage and not readily 'fitting into' an existing pattern of health and welfare services.

For these reasons medical practitioners were not always equipped to handle the problems of youth in a meaningful way, and some doctors had-and still do have-difficulty in empathising with this particular group.

That brings me to the nub of this report. It stresses the need for services designed particularly to deal with adolescents. We are finding in our society-it is a sad state of affairs but nevertheless a true one-that more and more social problems are developing with people of a younger age. In the past, those who were risk orientated, as the World Health Organisation terms them, tended to be about 18 or 19 years old. Now we are finding that this is developing as early as 12 or 13 years of age.

If one approaches any of the youth hostels in Western Australia, particularly those run by Jesus People Inc., one will find that their area of concern is those children who tend to leave their homes at a much younger age than was ever envisaged some 20 or 30 years ago. Perhaps children of 12 and 13 years of age left home, or were forced to leave home by the attitudes of their parents and the societal problems that their families were experiencing, years ago. If they did, I do not think the community was aware of it. The community is certainly aware of it now. It is a mental health problem. It creates specific difficulties for organisations in the community which are endeavouring to cater for the needs of those people. The situation is particularly difficult when we have a government which is continually cutting out the funds of various professional organisations which would be in a position most able to assist. On page 20, the report says:
Health professionals and others who work with youth recognise that:
adolescents tend to under-utilise existing health services;
some adolescents need encouragement to access needed health services;
adolescents need health care providers who are able to relate comfortably and with empathy;
there are benefits to be derived from grouping adolescents together in treatment areas.

I am aware that there are a number of tertiary institutions throughout our society which have health counsellors available to people who attend the particular tertiary institution. My prime concern-because my time is limited I will be very brief on this matter-is for people who do not ever get to a tertiary institution. I do not know of any high school which has more than a counsellor available to provide any emotional back-up service for adolescents going through high school. Many children in our society, both male and female, leave school at the end of their third year, at the end of their fourth year or at the end of their fifth year of high school and never attend a tertiary institution. Therefore they are not able to take advantage of those institutions which do have a health counselling service available to them. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DETERMINATION OF CHIEF AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL OFFICER

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome this report; it is the last of the reports that will be based on what I regard as inaccurate figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Quite simply put, the Representation Act determines the allocation of seats to States, based on the population in those States. This report indicates that there will be no redistribution of boundaries based on population changes within Australia between States. One of the great complaints of Victorians is that the figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are based on the census figures. Strangely enough, they are not really an accurate guide to the population in each State. In previous censuses the population has been determined on where a person resided on the night on which the census was taken.

The problem for Victoria is that because of our, let us say, less than welcome weather in winter, when the census is always taken, at least 60,000 Victorians go to Queensland to get into the sunshine. That means that every time the Bureau reports to the Chief Electoral Officer the population figure based on the June quarter or whatever, 60,000 Victorians are deprived of representations because the original base figure is wrong. I found it a great relief and an encouragement that in the last census two questions were asked-firstly, 'Where were you on the night on which the Census was taken?' and, secondly, 'Where do you normally reside?'. That will mean in future that about 60,000 Victorians will be put back into the State of Victoria. That has implications not only in terms of redistribution but also in terms of Commonwealth Government grants to each State.

When the allocation of seats was made Victoria had a quota of 32.56 per cent. We needed a drop of only 0.01 per cent to lose a House of Representatives seat. That would have been most unfair, based on the fact that 60,000 of our population were never calculated in the figures. Of course Senator Tate would be worried by the fact that under this scheme Tasmania is really entitled to only 3.5 per cent of the seats but because it is an original State it has five seats. I am not really criticising that but some sort of flexibility should be shown to the other States that are right on the borderline. I welcome this report; it will be the last one based on false figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Victoria get an extra seat for those 60,000?

—No, Victoria will not get an extra seat but it will mean that in future, probably for the next three or four years, we will retain that seat. That is all predicated on the question of whether the population will continue to desert Victoria. The answer to that is, of course, that because of the current State Liberal Government people are flocking out of Victoria to the National Party heaven in Queensland. However, I can assure honourable senators that after May next year, with a Cain-led Labor Government, people will flock from all over Australia back into Victoria. I am assured that the next time one of these reports comes down we will have an extra seat.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (REBATE ON TRANSPORT COSTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-(2.18)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I thank Senator Carrick and the Government for the courtesy they are now showing to private members in allowing them to introduce and to move the second reading of private members Bills an this fashion and in allowing Bills to remain on the table for six months or whatever the period may be so that the public can have the chance of looking at problems such as the one to which this Bill relates. This Bill is not party political; it deals with the removal of the sales tax component from the unit cost of goods when calculating the amount of sales tax to be attributed. As will transpire from my second reading speech, the Australian Democrats do not have any firm answers but we want to identify the problem and to ask the Senate on a non-party basis to make contributions as to how the problem faced by people living in the outback and in the country areas might be overcome.

The tyranny of distance has shaped Australia's development as a country remote from the economic and cultural mainstream of the Western world. Some of these constraints were self imposed. On our doorstop we chose to ignore the great cultural heritage of the East. Blinder still, we have refused to learn the lessons Aboriginal people had to teach us about how to get along with each other and with the wide spaces and the harsh natural beauty of this wonderful country. As a nation we are beginning to throw off this tyranny of the mind, this unthinking narrowness, just as modern technology is moving us closer to the rest of the world in physical terms. Yet, for many Australians, the tyranny of distance still has very real meaning. I refer to the people who have refused to join the mad rush-one could say the insane rush-to the large urban centres of south eastern Australia where the majority of Australians now live.

This drift to the cities has slowed down but it is still continuing at a frightening rate. The 1966 census showed that 61.43 per cent of Australians was living in major urban centres and 16.89 per cent was living in rural areas. I repeat that in 1966 roughly 61 per cent of Australians was living in major urban areas and about 17 per cent was living in rural areas. Ten years later, the 1976 census showed that 64.65 per cent was living in major urban centres, an increase of approximately 3 per cent and only 13.89 per cent was in rural areas, a decrease of similar magnitude. The percentage of people living in 'other urban' centres has remained constant at approximately 21.5 per cent.

I am talking about the people who live and work on farms and on mining developments and the people who struggle to provide essential services to remote settlements and country towns, the people who provide us with over 70 per cent of our export income-an essential factor for the comfort enjoyed by the rest of us who live in the cities. I refer also to the people in Alice Springs, in Darwin, in Port Hedland and similar administrative centres providing back up facilities for outback areas. To them all, distance means higher living costs, dearer petrol, limited employment opportunities, exorbitant telephone charges if they want to talk to friends and relatives in other parts of the country and outrageous travel costs if they want to see them. It means limited educational, social welfare and health facilities. It means the insidious, ever increasing transport costs, reflected not only in the lower disposable income of families but also in higher manufacturing and marketing costs for industry and primary producers, reducing their ability to compete and hindering the establishment of new markets. The Australian Democrats intend to promote decentralisation of industry and to work for opportunities and living conditions for people in the outback equal to those of people in urban areas.

This Bill that I am introducing-and I am proud to introduce-the Sales Tax Assessment (Rebate for Transport Costs) Bill 1981-as a private member's Bill is designed to attack one of the difficulties faced by people and industry outside major urban centres. It seeks to exempt from sales tax that portion of the taxable amount which represents the cost of transport. The desirability of this measure is clear: People paying sales tax on goods which have a high freight component, that is, people or producers living or working in areas outside major population areas, pay a disproportionately higher amount of sales tax where the freight component is included in the wholesale price of goods taxed.

Let me give a simple example. Those honourable senators who are not Victorians will excuse me for giving a Victorian example. A manufacturer of a desk in Wangaratta would need to include the cost of transporting all parts required for the desk. This already puts him at a disadvantage with his counterpart or competitor in Melbourne. However, in addition, he pays-and ultimately the purchaser of the desk pays-sales tax on these freight charges, further reducing his ability as a country manufacturer to compete with his city counterpart. Similarly, sales tax applies to goods transported and sold by wholesalers in country areas to people living in those areas. This means people living in those areas are at a disadvantage compared with the people who live in the cities. Clearly, it is equitable to exclude the freight component from the amount on which sales tax is levied. If the aim is clear I am afraid the mechanics to achieve it are less so.

The Asprey Taxation Review Committee considered this issue and, while expressing the view that equity did require change, concluded that it was very difficult to bring it about. The Democrats acknowledge and respect that view but do not accept it as a sufficient reason for this Parliament to do nothing. The Bill seeks to achieve sales tax exemption for the freight component by enabling taxpayers to claim a rebate at the time of making their return for sales tax payable to the Commissioner. In this way the creation of separate administrative machinery is avoided. In turn, the taxpayer would be obliged to obtain information and to maintain records adequate to substantiate the rebates he or she claims.

This latter aspect particularly requires close scrutiny by the people entitled to make claims and it is this consideration which has induced us to specify a commencement date of 1 July 1983, which provides ample time for consultation with all parties affected by this Bill. In other words, the Democrats are saying: 'Here is a problem affecting people who live in country areas. An inequity is being suffered by you'. We do not have any specific solutions, nor did the Asprey Committee. But we have put forward one possible solution: We are asking those people who live in the outback and in country areas to tell us, the senators of their own States and their local members of the House of Representatives, whether the Democrats way is a clumsy way of overcoming this problem. Are there better ways? We believe that it is right and proper to allow until 1 July 1983 for people to make representations on this matter.

In conclusion, let me quote some cost of living figures which demonstrate more clearly why the Democrats have persisted with the attempt to overcome at least some of the difficulties imposed by the tyranny of distance. I refer to the experimental retail price index prepared by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The index established a standard cost of living figure by averaging the actual cost of major food items in the six capital cities. This figure '100' is then compared with prices of a similar basket of items in other places. On this basis, in 1980 the Queensland towns of Mount Isa and Weipa rated 113 and 126 respectively; in Western Australia, Derby rated 119, Kununurra 135, Marble Bar 136, Port Hedland 115; in the Northern Territory, Alice Springs rated 111, Darwin 114 and Katherine 118. I ask: Where is the justice, where is the equity, that forces people living in those towns and those areas to pay that much more for the basic necessities of life? As a country we have no right to expect people to live and work in these places, to bear the hardships and disadvantages of isolation and, on top of that, to accept additional living costs of this order. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will amend the income tax law in two respects. Firstly the Bill will give effect to decisions taken by the Government to reduce the taxable value of the right that certain employees have to occupy free, or at low cost, residential accommodation provided by their employers. The Bill will also give effect to the proposal announced on 11 August 1981 that payments made to induce a person to return to work be made subject to income tax and liable to pay-as-you-earn tax instalment deductions.
EMPLOYEES' HOUSING
The first measure proposed by this Bill will implement the undertaking given by the Government in connection with the settlement of the Queensland coal miners' strike of last year.

In securing settlement of the dispute it was agreed that the income tax law would be amended to provide a more concessional basis for assessing the value to the miners of the residential accommodation provided to them by their employers.

The benefit of this concession will extend to employees in other industries who also live and work in remote areas if it is customary in the industry concerned for employers to provide free or subsidised housing for their employees.

In addition, after giving careful consideration to representations that it received on behalf of employers and employees engaged in the sugar industry, the Government has decided that the concession is also to be available for employees who meet certain additional criteria. These are persons who, while not living and working in remote areas, have no alternative to occupying accommodation supplied by their employers either because there is not suitable accommodation available in close proximity to the work place, or because they are required by their employers to live close to the work place and be on call for duty.

Again, availability of the concession in this extended way will depend on it being customary in the particular industry in which the taxpayer is engaged for employers to provide free or subsidised housing for their employees. For persons who do not live and work in areas remote from major centres of population it will also be a requirement that the employer provides accommodation for at least five other employees engaged at, or in association with, the place at which the taxpayer is employed.

In deciding to extend this concession to workers in the mining industry and to others similarly placed in other industries, the government has recognised that large numbers of employees are required, in following their employment, to reside and work in areas remote from large centres of population where they do not have access to many of the amenities and conveniences of urban living.

In accepting that the concession should also extend in certain cases to housing provided in non-remote areas, the Government has recognised that in some instances employees have no realistic alternative other than to occupy accommodation provided by their employers and that the conditions under which such accommodation is occupied are often onerous by reason of factors such as close proximity to the work place.

The concessional basis of valuation for income tax purposes proposed in the Bill will limit the amount to be included in the assessable income of an eligible employee, in respect of benefits granted by way of employer-provided housing, to 10 per cent of the market rental value of the accommodation, less the amount of any rent paid by the employee for use of the accommodation.

The Bill also provides that, as a general rule, future changes in the market rental value of accommodation provided to an employee will be geared to annual movements in the rental component of the consumer price index as measured for the capital city of the State in which the accommodation is situated.

I turn now to the criteria set out in the Bill to establish whether or not employer-provided accommodation is to be regarded as being in an area remote from a major centre of population for these purposes.

It is proposed that urban centres that had a population of 12,000 or more at the date of the 1976 census be classed as major population centres and that a location be classed as remote if it is not in, or adjacent to, such a major population centre.

Places of employment and locations of relevant accommodation that are within 100 km by the shortest practicable surface route of the centre of a city shown at the time of the 1976 census to have had a population exceeding 130,000 people or that are within 40 km of a town or city that had at that time a population of 12,000 or more people will be regarded as being adjacent to a major population centre and therefore not qualifying for concessional treatment on the basis of remoteness. Such accommodation may qualify, however, if the alternative tests to which I have referred are satisfied.

The Commissioner of Taxation is also to have power, where all the circumstances warrant it, to treat a person who lives or works in, or in an area adjacent to, a major population centre so defined as living or working outside that area if persons living or working near that person fall to be regarded as being in a remote area under these rules. This is to obviate different tax results being applied to near neighbours.

The measures proposed by the Bill concerning employee housing benefits will operate from the commencement of the 1977-78 income year and the commissioner of taxation will have power to amend assessments made before the provisions come into operation so as to effect any reduction in the value of assessable housing benefits brought about by the new measures.
INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE SETTLEMENT PAYMENTS

Honourable senators will recall that when the industrial dispute on the Loy Yang power station project was settled late last year, payments made to dismissed employees who returned to work were described and paid, under the settlement agreement, in such a way that no tax was payable on the payments.

The payments which were based on the wages that the employees might have been expected to receive during the period of their dismissal if they had remained at work during that period were declared as being to compensate employees for hardship suffered during the dispute. But in the Government's view the payments were designed principally to induce the employees to return to work, and if they had been so described, or if they had been paid in respect of a period of employment rather than of a period of dismissal, the payments would have been fully taxable.

At that time the Treasurer announced that the Government was examining the question of whether similar payments made in future, should be made subject to tax, and on 11 August 1981 he announced the Government's decision that any such payments made under arrangements entered into after that date would be fully subject to income tax.

In broad terms, the Bill will amend the income tax law to include in the assessable income of a taxpayer any amount paid to him or her under an agreement, arrangement or understanding entered into after 11 August 1981 for the purpose of achieving the result that the taxpayer would, or but for special circumstances would, resume performing work or rendering services.

The Bill will also provide that payments made after the end of the month in which this legislation receives the royal assent are to be subject to pay-as-you-earn tax instalment deductions, at a rate to be prescribed in the income tax regulations-that rate will be equivalent to the standard rate of personal tax (32 per cent for 1981-82).
Details of the technical aspects of the Bill are contained in an explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Honourable senators will be aware that clauses precluding spouses of persons involved in industrial action from receiving unemployment and special benefit were deleted by the Government from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 during its passage through the Parliament. This was done pursuant to a request of the Senate, not because the Government agreed with the request, but to prevent delay in the passage of the remainder of that Bill which, inter alia, authorised the payment of additional unemployment benefit to single beneficiaries aged 18 and over. In deleting those clauses, the Government announced that fresh legislation containing those provisions would be introduced at the first available opportunity.
This Bill introduces those provisions.

Before October 1979, the Social Services Act precluded payment of unemployment benefit to a person who was a direct participant in a strike. However, it enabled unemployment benefit to be paid at the 'married' rate to the spouse of a person ineligible for unemployment benefit on those grounds. The Act was subsequently amended to provide that unemployment benefit payable to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action was to be at the 'single' rate. A further amendment precluded payment of special benefit to a person who, because of industrial action, was not qualified to receive unemployment benefit. This Bill now proposes that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwillingness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker, because they have become voluntarily unemployed or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment.

Consistent with this approach, special benefit will also be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances. The Government has decided, however, that if a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, their spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children.

Mr President, we are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes. What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne. The Government holds strongly to the belief that these provisions should become law. In the case of the provisions relating to industrial action, we do not believe that Australian taxpayers should be asked to subsidise strike action through the social welfare system. Trade unions choosing to take such action make a free decision to strike. If they choose to take such action, they should bear the consequences of their action, not the tax-paying community. Trade unions cannot expect, in those circumstances, that the rest of the community will pick up the bill for the support of the families of members of the trade union involved in the strike.

The legislation as it stands at the moment permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions. Unless frivolously or maliciously entered into, the object of a strike is to obtain, by the exercise of economic pressure directed against the employer, a benefit for those who take such action. As a result, the benefit sought is itself economic, such as increased pay, a shorter working week, or special allowances. Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike.

The point to be emphasised is that to strike is an exercise in freedom of choice. It is one taken by the membership of a union to promote its own interests and only its own interests. It is taken against the interests of the employer and, what is directly relevant to this Bill, it is one which is not taken in the interests of the community as a whole.

Indeed, the effect of strike action is often in conflict with the interests of the community as a whole or some part of it. Frequently, the community suffers as a result of strike action. This may be reflected simply in inconvenience or in terms of direct economic cost. Furthermore, in a larger sense, it may be said that in the longer term the community always suffers as the cumulative result of the strike action is to decrease the availability of goods and services, and sometimes to do great damage to particular sectors of the economy, or to particular employers.

These matters need only to be mentioned to make clear the absurdity of any argument that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families, and should be paid by the community at large. For it is the community at large that provides through taxation the funds from which strikers are presently paid the benefits that this Bill proposes to eliminate.

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the workforce themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them. This has enabled them, under the existing legislation, to obtain unemployment benefit, and so transfer to the taxpayer some of the real cost of the industrial action taken by their husbands.

So, the Australian public is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs that result from the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in the strike.

To act to correct this situation is not to 'punish' the families of strikers, but to ensure that people accept the financial consequences of their own actions and do not look to the rest of the community to bear the costs.

Similarly, there is no good reason why the community should automatically and immediately be expected to assume the normal financial responsibilities of people who are not willing to work, who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job, or who are dismissed through their own misconduct. This is happening at present, because the spouses of such people can register for employment in their own right and, if they are unable to obtain employment, can claim unemployment benefit both for themselves and for their 'dependent' spouses.

Mr President, we believe that whether people refuse to work because of industrial action or whether, in some other way, they show themselves unwilling to enter or remain in the workforce, there is no reason why the rest of the community should shoulder their financial responsibilities.
This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequences of their actions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) the progress, or lack of it, in attempts to finalise reciprocal social security pension agreements between Australia and countries such as Italy, Greece, West Germany, Holland, et cetera. It seems to me that this matter has been going on since 1972 or 1973. We have had frequent consultations between the various governments, particularly between the Italian and Australian governments. I know that it is a difficult problem, with most countries-whence we get our migrants having contributory pension schemes and Australia having non-contributory schemes. But it seems that if a government such as the Italian Government can arrange reciprocal agreements with Canada and the United States and with most unlikely countries such as Argentina and Brazil, we should be able to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: There are probably in excess of 10,000 Italian pensioners in this country. There are 2,500 to 3,000 Australian pensioners in Italy. Their situation is confused. The communities, as I am sure the Minister knows, are anxious that some sort of an agreement be reached. The Italian Government seems to think that there has been sufficient consultation and a sufficient exchange of ideas. The position of some West German migrants in this country is difficult. Those who have taken Australian citizenship can get their reciprocal pensions only if they have an address in West Germany. This creates all sorts of problems for them. I think it also leads to a lot of misunderstanding. When are such agreements likely to be finalised? How often in the future will Italian officials and politicians have to come to Australia and how often will Australian officials and politicians have to go to Italy, for instance, before we get some satisfactory arrangement for those groups which make up a considerable proportion of our community now and who, as they age, will make up an even greater proportion?

I noticed in yesterday's Hobart Mercury a statement from Senator Walters amazingly headed 'Everyone protected in health scheme'. Of course, the Government admitted on Tuesday night that that is just not so. Senator Walters claimed that Australia's new health scheme had got off to an encouraging start, which I think is an amazing statement in view of the confusion and shambles which have been shown up and admitted by the Government.
—They live in their own world of fantasy.

—I suppose they have to try to convince themselves that the decision they made was correct. But it is fantasy, as Senator Walsh suggests. The figures that the Government admitted on Tuesday night were that on the medical side 89 per cent of the population were covered in one way or another and that on the hospital side 93 per cent were covered in one way or another by private insurance, health cards or by a repatriation or defence provision for health services. What that indicates is that 11 per cent on the medical side and 7 per cent on the hospital side are not covered at all.
—You have left out part of what I said.

—I will acknowledge the point that Senator Peter Baume made. Seven per cent of the Australian population is one million people. One million people do not have health coverage. The point that Senator Baume was trying to make sure I acknowledged was that a proportion of people who are eligible for health cards have not yet applied for them and that it is not too late for them to apply because, if eligible, they have 13 weeks after any treatment in which to obtain a card.
—And people in Queensland.

—And people in Queensland. Even if the number of people were half a million it is still amazing for the Government to admit that there is that proportion of people who are not covered. I am sure he will not suggest that it is half a million people who are well off and who do not even feel the need for health insurance. A fair proportion of that number would be people who just missed out on being entitled to a health card, who are still in a category of great need and who cannot afford to take out health insurance. The other aspect of the Government's admission about people on low incomes who are eligible for health cards was Senator Chaney's admission that 40 per cent of those who are likely to be eligible have not applied. Even if one acknowledges the point that there is time for people who have had treatment to obtain a card retrospectively, it does not say much for the Government's selling of the scheme and its publicity about it. The Government has had to admit that 40 per cent of those whom it suggests are likely to be eligible have not yet claimed a card.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has to indicate what it intends to do about this matter. I know that it will not acknowledge that its scheme is wrong, that it has made a wrong decision or that there should be improvements to it. The Government at least ought to be doing something more about publicising the health card arrangements so that that 40 per cent, who it says are eligible but have not yet obtained a card, do get one. Perhaps the Government could even acknowledge that its system of having a sharp cut-off point for the eligibility of a card does disadvantage a lot of people. Many of that million who are not covered are placed in a situation of being in need, being unable to afford health insurance, and they have missed out under the restrictive means test on eligibility for the health card.

TALK.START.PARA: (2.56)-A number of matters have been raised. Senator Grimes asked what progress had been made with respect to reciprocal agreements. There is a lack of coincidence between the basis of the Australian scheme and the bases of schemes applying in the countries with which we would be concerned to have reciprocal agreements-countries such as Italy, Germany and Greece, which have contributed many of our migrants. The fact that those countries have contribution-based systems and that we have a more universal tax-based system gives rise to problems in merging the two systems in the sort of reciprocal agreements, that apply between, say, European countries. The matter is one which has been receiving steady attention from the Government. Senator Grimes is right in saying that meetings have taken place between officials of various countries. There have also been visits by politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have held this portfolio, I have had a number of meetings with representatives of some of our key migrant donor countries and they have expressed their interest in making progress towards reaching reciprocal agreements. I have taken part in a series of discussions with other involved Ministers, and there have been a great many discussions at the official level. I am now a fair way along the track in drawing up a submission which can be put before the Government. At present further interdepartmental discussions are taking place. I have settled on what I regard as an appropriate draft for circulation to other departments. I am not able to say whether it has been sent out; it may well have, as I saw the relevant officers of my Department on the matter some weeks ago. As to when progress might be expected, I am a little cautious about giving a date. If I had been asked to do so at the time of the Supplementary Estimates, I would have said that I would expect some initial Government decisions to be taken by now. I would like to be quite frank with the Senate and say that it is a fairly difficult problem and it is not easy to see which is the best next move to take.

Honourable senators who are interested in the subject will be aware that progress was made with reciprocal agreements in the early part of the 1970s. The Whitlam Government, with its decision to grant general portability of pensions in 1973, changed the shape of the Australian system in a way that made the agreements reached to that point largely irrelevant. The matter is one in which there have indeed been difficulties. We are working on them at the moment. I should like to see progress made late this year or early next year but I would be cautious about giving a precise date because there are difficult issues to be determined. I certainly accept that this is seen as a matter of importance by many Australians who spent part of their lives in another country, their country of birth.

There is not a great deal that I would wish to say in relation to the points raised by Senator Coates except to point out that it is not Senator Walters who writes the headlines in whatever newspaper it is. Senator Coates criticised Senator Walters for the headline which stated: 'Everyone protected in health scheme'. I simply say that those are not the words of Senator Walters. Senator Walters gave certain figures about an estimated 67.5 per cent of people being covered for medical costs and 71.6 per cent for hospital costs as at October 1981 compared with very much lower figures in March under the previous scheme. She pointed out that when one added in the number of pensioners, that is, 13.4 per cent of the population, the number of health care card holders, that is, 5.4 per cent of the population, and the number of repatriation pensioners and defence personnel, that is, 2.5 per cent of the population, this brings the total of the population who now have some insurance cover to 92.9 per cent. As Senator Coates himself pointed out, with respect to the balance who qualify for assistance under the protection which is given for those with low incomes, there is a retrospective entitlement if they seek care without having organised themselves to get a health care card. There is the opportunity for them to do that over a period of some 13 weeks. There is, of course, no time limit on their applying for a card prospectively. That entitlement is in place and it is there for their protection. It is an important distinction which is to be made about this scheme as against the pre-Medibank scheme which applied in Australia.

In relation to the total figure of about 7 per cent of people without any hospital cover, a number of those will be people who have chosen not to insure and who would not be in a low income category. That is a right which Australians are entitled to exercise. I suppose there is a percentage of young healthy people with good incomes who see themselves as running a fair sort of risk. That is not something which has been encouraged by the Government which has, of course, offered a taxation concession to people who take out insurance, a concession which has been welcomed by the substantial majority of Australians who do insure.

With respect to further publicity to ensure that those who are entitled to a card get it, I acknowledge that it is important that we watch the extent to which eligibility is taken up. But I remind the committee that whichever way one goes in this area one can be open to criticism. We were subjected to criticism from one front bencher in the Australian Labor Party who said that we were not advertising enough and from another who said that we were, in fact, spending taxpayers' money on propaganda when we advertised the scheme. So there is room for a difference of opinion as to the extent to which we ought to be going into advertising campaigns on these matters. But I note the point made by Senator Coates. I will see that we will give that further consideration as the year progresses.

In relation to the Queensland appeals tribunals, there has been discussion in the Senate from time to time about difficulties in the appeals system. Questions were asked, I think, by Senator Colston with respect to that. There were delays, as I recall, in the appointment of medical practitioners in Queensland. Those rates of pay have been increased. The appeals tribunal situation now is, as I recollect, satisfactory. I expect, therefore, that the discrepancy which shows a longer waiting time in Queensland would be one which ought to be reduced in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the troubled matter of the administration of invalid pensions which we raised at the Estimates committee hearings but which I do not believe was satisfactorily answered at that time. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, at the time seemed happy enough with the situation. He said that things had settled down in the area. But I and many others are far from satisfied that invalid pensioners, and particularly invalid pension applicants, are being seen to get justice from the Department of Social Security. In the eight years from 1972 to 1980, the number of invalid pensioners rose from 138,800 to 229,200. The number rose steadily over that period in line with the population increase-slightly faster but no faster in fact than the increase in every other category of social security pensions or benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: When what could be described as punitive action was taken against invalid pensioners by the tightening of the eligibility requirements after the famous legal opinion that was given to Mr Lanigan, the Director-General of the Department at the time, the numbers not only did not rise at the regular rate but also, probably for the first time since statistics were introduced, they began to drop. The number of invalid pensions paid has dropped in every month since May 1980. So instead of an eight per cent average increase which would have taken the number to about 250,000 we have had a regular drop which has decreased the number of invalid pensioner payments to 220,700. About 19,000 people who one could suggest would have been entitled to invalid pensions under the pre-1980 rules have been refused. That is a fairly liberal use of figures, I know, but it is an estimate which I believe one could make. The estimates this year have predicted an increase of 1,000, far fewer than there would have been in any other year for which I have figures; but there is just no sign of that yet.

At the end of August the figures still showed a drop. More people seemed to have been knocked back for and fewer people put on invalid pensions. People are certainly able to appeal but it is difficult for them to take the steps which are often very daunting and to pit themselves against the bureaucracy and the medical experts of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health. I have no idea how many of the 19,000, or whatever the figure is, have a valid case for appealing, but the impression of those in the community with knowledge in this area is that only a tiny proportion of those who should appeal ever will appeal. The Department and the procedures do not make it easy because at the moment there are some hundreds of appeals before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. We learned during the Estimates Committee hearing that there is an average waiting time of five months for a decision. Over 100 cases are before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Appeals and rejections, I believe, would be less necessary if the Government would watch the use of what were the revised invalid pension guidelines which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) announced earlier this year but which seem in fact to have had virtually no impact, as the declining numbers of invalid pensioners demonstrate. Doctors are still required to make their assessments on medical evidence only. I know of nothing to indicate that they are given any background information on family circumstances or on work environment or are encouraged to take work history, age or any other factors into account.

This would be less serious, I suggest, if the Director-General of Social Security, or whoever his delegate is who makes decisions on pension grants, took a broader view than the very strict medical interpretation the Department of Health officers have been insisting on-under instructions, one would assume. In the Willie Panke case the Administrative Appeals Tribunal pointed out that it was the Department of Social Security's job to take the broader view. But even now I suggest the Department seems to be taking the view of the former Director-General, Mr Lanigan, that it is its job to keep the people off the invalid pension, not to put them on it. I think there is a great deal of room for improvement in the information about eligibility given by social security officers in the supporting evidence about applicants which the medical officers should have, and in the way the Department assesses applications after the medical reports have been received.

The two cases in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal upheld the appeals of rejected invalid pensioners make interesting reading but they will do nothing for present applicants unless the Department takes note of the more humane approach that has been suggested by the AAT. One can look at a further case which was conceded by the Department of Social Security at the eleventh hour. The Legal Service Bulletin of October last points out that in 1980 an applicant, Mr P. Stefyn, applied for an invalid pension. It was his third application in two years. He was aged 56 and had not worked since 1978. His application was based on chronic physical and emotional disabilities. The Department rejected his application. He appealed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the appeal was formally dismissed by a delegate of the Director-General in March 1981. In April 1981 the applicant consulted the Springvale Legal Service. According to three medical reports he was unemployable. Each of the doctors-two were psychiatrists and one was a general practitioner-examined Mr Stefyn a number of times. Mr Stefyn claimed that only one of the four doctors that the Department of Social Security had sent him to had given him a thorough examination.

The legal service applied to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review in April and in July Mr Stefyn was advised to make a fourth application for an invalid pension. He consulted the same three doctors and the legal service obtained up to date medical reports on the gentleman. His application was set down to be considered at a preliminary conference on 2 September. The Springvale Legal Service points out that another case was set down for the same day. The Department conceded in the other case on the day before it was to go to the preliminary conference. At the preliminary conference the Department was given copies of the medical reports. In the view of the legal service, the Department seemed determined to fight the case. It was thought that the Department wanted to use Mr Stefyn as a test case for applications based on psychiatric grounds. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearing was set down for 21 and 22 September this year. The Legal Service briefed a barrister who had been successful on other invalid pension applications. The three doctors who thought the gentleman was unemployable and the local State member of Parliament, who had taken up his case, were alerted. On 14 September the legal service sent its most recent report to the Department of Social Security. On the morning of 18 September, one working day before the hearing, the Department conceded.

The Springvale Legal Service asks a very pertinent question. It asks: Why? We cannot believe that one single medical report, which merely reiterated an earlier opinion by the same doctor, convinced the Department at the last minute. Perhaps it was the opinion of the Department of Social Security doctor who examined Stefyn on his fourth application, 10 days before the date of the hearing. Perhaps the Department of Social Security did not feel confident enough to put the AAT to the test again after the Panke and Reid cases. Too many adverse decisions in the AAT would put pressure on the Department of Social Security to review its policy in the area of invalid pensions. The legal service makes the point that the conceding of Mr Stefyn's case indicates the Department's uncertainty in the face of an administrative appeals tribunal which has real teeth and shows greater sensitivity towards incapacitated people in today's labour market.

I think it is fair to say that even though the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is a quasi-judicial body, and the reputation of such bodies is not often considered to be particularly humane, its decisions would seem to be more humane than the Department's. Can the Minister comment on the Department's experiences in this area, particularly in respect of cases that have gone to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal? The delays and trauma are considerable for people who are incapacitated. A further point that I would like clarified is whether the Government is likely to accept the recommendation of the Australian Council of Social Service that if an applicant is unhappy with a Commonwealth medical officer's assessment he should be able to request an additional medical examination, the cost of which should be reimbursed by the Department of Health. I think there is real concern that invalid pensioners are not being and have not been given a fair go. This all seems to coincide with the production of the directive control of invalid pensions by the former Director-General. One was led to believe earlier by the announcements of the Minister for Social Security that the whole situation would change. As the Minister said, he thought that the whole thing had settled down. The figures seem to give us some reason for concern. The repeated reports that all of us have received of the difficulties faced by people seeking invalid pensions would seem to indicate that, in fact, the situation may not have settled down. One wonders whether the Minister has had any further thoughts on this matter since the Estimates Committee hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes raised again the question of invalid pensions. I cannot say that there has been very much change since the time of the Estimates committees. Since that time we have been largely concerned with parliamentary proceedings and it has not been a time of particularly active policy development, examination and review. However, he did raise some of the interesting facts and figures in this area. I will quote his figures because, although I have not independently checked them, they are certainly in accord with the broad picture as I recall it. For example, he quoted an increase in the number of invalid pensioners from 138,000 to 229,000 over a period of eight years. Whilst he said that that figure is increasing at a faster rate than the increase in population but is no faster than increases in the numbers of other beneficiaries, I would say only that that is not necessarily a very consoling or convincing point to make. The fact is that over roughly the same period there was a considerable increase in the level of unemployment, for example.

It is a matter in which one can be fairly non-partisan. The graphs paint a very clear picture. From about 1974 there was a very substantial increase. The increase continued for a period after we came to office and it has become stable over recent years with some slight reductions over the last year and a half or so. There has been a very substantial change in what would be regarded as the average level of unemployment over the last five, six or seven years-in fact, since 1974-as against the prior period. The annual rate of increase in the number of pensioners-again I quote from memory-is in excess of 6 per cent per annum, whereas the increase in the number of people of pensionable age has increased by slightly over 2 per cent per annum. So I do not get much consolation from the suggestion that the increase in invalid pensions is necessarily in order because those pensions are going up at the same rate as are other pensions and benefits. I suppose the question that has to be asked is whether it is a fact that at any time a quarter of a million Australians who wish to work are 85 per cent incapacitated for work.

There were elements of the invalid pension system which I think were undesirable. I speak, of course, from reports because that period precedes my involvement in the portfolio. There were elements of unevenness in the administration of the tests for the invalid pension and I think the substantial and positive change which was made was designed to ensure a more even application of the rules. I think it is comprehended outside and within the Parliament that we have made a considerable effort to ensure that the invalid pension guidelines are adequate and understandable and that they meet the requirements of the Act. Those guidelines were published in, I think, last May and were sent to the people who have to apply them. We prepared those guidelines after consultation, including consultation with the Australian Council of Social Service, and we have made a very substantial effort to achieve a satisfactory situation in that area.

Senator Grimes has now raised the fact that appeals are coming before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that some of these appeals succeed. He has asked whether this does not indicate that things are still wrong. I can only say to the Committee again that I would have thought that it was common ground that the whole point of having an appeal system was to have something which subjects our administrative processes to external check. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal in its jurisdiction in this area will have proved to have been rather fruitless if, over the years in a range of areas, it does not tell us that on occasions our administration is not correct, that on occasions we are not applying the law correctly, and so on. It has been given that jurisdiction precisely to perform that task. If one got a pattern in the cases coming before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which suggested that the administration was not in accordance with the law or that wrong decisions were being made, then of course one would have to look to the administrative processes to see what ought to be changed to remove the objection.

The Panke case was raised. That was one of the early invalid pension cases to come before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is my view, after looking at the records of that case, and the view of my advisers, that nothing in the decision which was made by the Tribunal in that case conflicts with the guidelines of eligibility which we released in May of this year. It cannot be said that the decision totally endorses the guidelines; it does not necessarily cover all aspects of the guidelines. Therefore we cannot say that they are for all time to be accepted as the proper guide to the meaning of the Act. But on the issues which are dealt with by the Tribunal it appears to us that the Tribunal's views are consistent with the guidelines which we laid down in May. The fact that the Tribunal overturned the decision of the Department in the Panke case indicates the proposition that the guidelines had not been correctly applied in that case. Again, I say that the Tribunal is there to pick up those cases where there is some administrative error and hence some detriment to the subject.

In light of the decision, officers of the Department are currently consulting with officers of the Department of Health, for two reasons. They may have completed these consultations now; the last advice I had was that they were in the process of consultation. They wanted firstly to see whether any other matters awaiting hearing before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal might be settled prior to hearing and, secondly, to review administrative procedures for the application of the guidelines so as to further increase the probability of their being correctly and consistently applied.

I see the AAT as being a very valuable safeguard for the citizen, a means whereby the Department and the Minister as required are reminded of how the law should be applied. I believe that it will be a very valuable improvement to the system. I say that I do not believe that it will be productive to complain about the fact that when one puts a formal appeal mechanism into place formal steps are taken in the way that steps have to be taken in the lead-up to a formal hearing with the briefing of counsel, the further checking of evidence and the obtaining of further evidence where that is thought necessary by the appellant or by the respondent.

It will also be true that cases will be settled before hearing when that pre-trial or pre-hearing examination shows that perhaps there is some defect, something has been overlooked or some fresh evidence has come to light. So the steps which were outlined by Senator Grimes when he was referring to a case referred to in the Legal Service Bulletin are steps which are familiar to anybody who has been engaged in the process of litigation or in the process of appeal, and of necessity they are the sorts of steps which occur now that we have that formal avenue of appeal for people who feel that the social security system has not given them the decision to which they are entitled.

I can assure the Committee, however, and I assure Senator Grimes, that the decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be carefully watched by my Department and where they indicate deficiencies in administration of course those deficiencies will be addressed. I believe it is too early to say that the changes to the guidelines which were introduced in May will overcome deficiencies. I do not rule out that possibility for the future. That may, of course, occur.

As far as the matters raised by Senator Coates are concerned, I cannot give him the sort of detail that he would like about the costs of the administration of the scheme simply because it would be impossible at this stage. It seems to me that we could alleviate the costs to the taxpayer and the anxiety caused to veterans if we approached this problem from another angle and looked quite carefully at the various categories that come before the Remuneration Tribunal and considered whether they should be there. This may seem as though it were a licence to spend money but, indeed, I believe that in many cases it could effectively save money. I will seek, probably in the next session, to bring forward a private member's Bill in relation to that if we cannot get any action in looking at categories of veterans.

I believe it is not only prisoners-of-war from campaigns such as World War I, World War II, Korea and Malaya who could be given automatic entitlement. Surely we could also give that entitlement to certain categories of injuries such as severe arthritis, arising out of World War II or the Korean engagement. I believe that one way of doing this might very well be to review in a systematic way the various claims that have been approved. If there is upwards of a reasonable percentage-that may be argued about-we could see whether these people could be granted automatic entitlement. For the sake of argument let us take 75 per cent of claims of veterans who came from a particular theatre of war with a particular range of complaints. If 75 per cent of these claims, say, in the last five or 10 years, have been successful why not take that group of veterans and, if any further people from that theatre of war apply with claims that fall basically within those areas, grant them automatic entitlement?

In other words, let us unclog the system. Unless something is done I believe extreme hardship will continue to be visited on many of our veterans who feel disillusioned with the system. I am merely raising the point that we could all reply to the letters we all get from various veterans who served their country in, say, the the First World War, the Second World War or whatever, which state that they have fought for two and a half years, three years, or four years to get a claim heard and that it has been adjourned, brought up again and adjourned again. We have to look at taking some of the veterans out of the system by having automatic entitlement.

I do not believe that one voice in the community would be raised against such an action. I think it is only by taking such a bold type of initiative in this area that we may be able to give justice to those veterans and set about refining our procedures so that never again will we get into a situation where somebody has to wait more than a maximum of six months to have his claim heard and reviewed. I believe that should be the maximum length of time taken within the system, given the fact that from now on we can keep much more comprehensive records within the Department of Defence and that we will be able to understand the problems of veterans much more sympathetically and in much more depth. Even if these types of things occur we may very well see in years to come the appropriation for the Department of Veterans' Affairs shrinking if not down to the bottom of the list, then well down to the bottom. The difficulties in the appeals system are fundamental to the system and, of course, are of the greatest concern to not only me as Minister but also officers in my Department. It is true that over the years there has been a substantial growth in the time it has taken to process, through the various levels of appeal within the Department, various applications for pensions and/or treatment. I think we need to review the history of this matter over the last few years in order to get it into proper perspective. In 1977 there was a very substantial change to the repatriation system as a result of the Toose report which was, I think, initially commissioned by the Whitlam Labor Government in 1972. This change involved the provision of reasons in respect of individual cases being heard by repatriation boards and the Repatriation Commission and, of course, that led to a very substantial amount of extra work being loaded on to the members of those appeal bodies in such a way that it very substantially slowed down the operation and decision making processes of the bodies. There was also a superimposition, if you like, upon the then appeal system which went no further than the Repatriation Commission at that time, of a further appeal system which was made up of the Repatriation Review Tribunal composed of semi-judicial people. Of course references now can go further to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, from there to the Federal Court of Australia and eventually to the High Court.

What I am pointing out to honourable senators is that the enormous changes that have occurred in the appeal system over the last five or six years have led to a different kind of appeal system to the one that previously applied. From memory, I can quote some rather graphic statistics to show honourable senators what differences this has caused. As I recall, at the Repatriation Board level, in 1970, the number of cases processed was some 30,000. In the latest year that I have in my mind the number processed was about 13,000, a drop of almost two-thirds. At that same time the number of people handling cases at the board level increased, I think, from three to nine. If those numbers are not correct they are of that order. The point about this is that there has been a very substantial fall in the number of cases being heard through the system and a very substantial increase in the number of people handling appeals within the Department, yet the number of days taken in order to process the appeals at all levels in the system has grown very substantially.

This indicates that there have been major changes and the effects of those changes have been to take the system further out than previously applied and this has led to the kinds of problems that we now see. The reasons for the changes have been substantially supported by ex-service organisations because these changes do bring benefits to the ex-serviceman. I think Senator Macklin would acknowledge that the system, rather than being inflexible, is full of opportunities for people to test their eligibility at various levels to an extent greater than would have applied before the amendments in 1977. Consequently, it is not without some concern that the result has been the extension of time to process these individual cases.

Having said all that and, I hope, having set out the background of the problem I acknowledge that there is substantial difficulty and that we need to address our minds to this problem. Along those lines, my Department is having discussions with the ex-service organisations, particularly the Returned Services League, in regard to methods by which we can change this process and in some way improve the situation. More particularly, in recent times we have appointed more people to repatriation boards, created more boards and established single delegates at the Commission level in order to be able to handle applications more quickly.

I take on board the points Senator Macklin made. They are matters which I think deserve examination. I understand that on the morning prior to the meeting of Senate Estimates Committee H, which was on Monday, 12 October, what might be called a dry run was organised and presided over by the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry at which all the first assistant secretaries were lined up and presented with the sorts of questions which it was anticipated they might receive from the Senate Estimates Committee. There are several items in the appropriations which I could raise; for example, item 309-Rural re-establishment loans for veterans. Many of the veterans settled on the land after World War II were, of course, settled in the Riverland area of South Australia, an area which has had substantial economic problems for many years and which has a particular problem at this stage because of the very heavy production of canned fruit last year, both factors in the area having produced an extraordinarily large stockpile, and the diminishing overseas sales of canned fruit. I am informed that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), at a meeting in the Riverland last Monday, gave two reasons in response to questions from the fruit growers assembled as to why the Government had not up to this stage taken any action and, indeed, only a couple of weeks ago had got around to sending a reference on canned fruit to the Industries Assistance Commission. Perhaps I should more accurately say that he gave two excuses. The first was that the Government could not take any action and could not send off a reference to the IAC because the industry could not agree on what it wanted. Of course, that is the oldest Country Party subterfuge in the book.

Secondly, and more importantly, he said that the Government's hands were tied because of the Industries Assistance Commission Act and the requirement under the Act for matters to be referred to the Commission for investigation, inquiry and report prior to new forms of assistance being granted to industry. That might have been superficially a valid reason but it conflicts with one historical precedent and one contemporary precedent. The historical precedent was set in 1977 when on the eve of an election, without any reference to the IAC, the Government suddenly introduced its stupid $10 a head of stock assistance to beef producers. That $10 a head was paid to beef producers for, amongst other things, sterilising female cattle. Less than two years later there was a heavy demand and extremely high prices for cattle, the sterilisation of which the Government had subsidised in 1977-78, which should have been mated so that their progeny would be ready for the market in 1978-79. That is the sort of crass incompetence we expect from this Government, with its Ministry dominated by the rednecks of the National Country Party.

Of course, that is not the real issue. The real issue is that in 1977 the constraints of the Industries Assistance Commission Act were not at all important. Straight off the top of Malcolm Fraser's head, the source of all the most crass schemes which this Government has introduced, came this beef industry assistance scheme which in the end cost a cool $117m. It was pointed out at the meeting last Monday that it was done then, and Richard-I am sorry, Peter-Nixon replied that that was done during an election campaign. I presume that the implication of that remark is that the law of the land is suspended when the Fraser Government is in the midst of an election campaign.

The contemporary precedent is that there will be introduced into the Parliament-it has been deferred by the Government until the autumn session-a Dried Sultanas Production Underwriting Bill. No reference was given to the IAC as to whether such an underwriting scheme could be introduced without prior IAC inquiry and report. Senator Durack was asked yesterday by Senator McLaren whether the Minister for Primary Indusry or anyone else has sought an opinion on the legality of that Dried Sultanas Production Underwriting Bill vis-a-vis the Industries Assistance Commission Act. Senator Durack said he could not answer a question like that off the top of his head, which is not surprising. Senator McLaren then asked him whether he could bring an answer into the Senate today. Senator Durack said he would initiate inquiries and do his best. It has not yet arrived. The defence that I anticipated from the Government was that a general inquiry into fruit growing was conducted by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1975 and that that inquiry satisfies the requirements of the Industries Assistance Commission Act so far as the Dried Sultanas Underwriting Bill is concerned.

I pass no opinion about whether that would be an adequate response but I put on the record that the Government cannot have it both ways. If 'Richard' Nixon is to use the 1975 general reference on fruit growing as a justification, a validation, of the Dried Sultanas Underwriting Bill, it could be argued with equal validity that some assistance to canned fruit growers could have been initiated by the Government without further reference to the IAC for inquiry and report. In other words, Mr Nixon at that stage was following the time-honoured custom of National Country Party Ministers when caught in difficult positions-that is, to say anything that comes into their heads if it looks as if it will get them off the hook for the time being, then, when they are next cornered, to repeat the process. I have some other matters to raise but I think the officers and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) have now had sufficient time in which to consult before answering the couple of questions which I put forward at the beginning of my remarks.

If he did so, I congratulate him for either his perspicacity or his good fortune. Those honourable senators who cast their minds back to the position in 1977 will recall that that was a period when beef growers were in considerable difficulties in many parts of Australia. As I recall it there were both seasonal and market reasons-I speak from recollection-for the beef industry in Australia being in difficulty in that year. As a result, the Government took action which provided for payments to beef growers only under very limited circumstances.
