—The first matter I raise is that of the apprehension of Taiwanese fishermen who infringe Australian laws. During Estimates committee hearings I asked some questions about the apprehension of Taiwanese fishermen and the cost to the Australian taxpayer of that apprehension. An article in today's Canberra Times states that a Taiwanese fisherman faces gaol because he is unable to pay fines totalling $6,000 imposed by a court in Queensland. He has infringed Australian laws relating to fishing within Australian fishing zones. He will face a gaol term of six months if he cannot find that $6,000. One of the answers to my queries during the hearings of this Estimates Committee was that it cost the Australian taxpayer about $9,000 to apprehend these people. So even with this fine of $6,000 there is a discrepancy of $3,000 between the fine and the cost of apprehension.
—There is probably some deterrent value.

—Apparently it is not of deterrent value because these people continually breach our fishing laws. By doing that they are depriving Australian fishermen of their living, in addition to the fact that in many cases they are fishing out many of the areas on which our own fishermen depend. I think the Government should take some action to see that these penalties are very much increased. I also ask whether any money is recovered by the Australian Government from the sale of these confiscated vessels. I was told that in some cases-I am speaking only from memory now-the captains of these vessels were able to buy them back by tender. So it does not appear to me that the fines that are imposed are a deterrent to these people. They seem to be continually breaching our fishing laws. Has the Government, through the Department of Primary Industry, which handles the fishing industry in Australia, given any consideration to tightening up the laws and to making these penalties much greater so that we will have a deterrent, as was suggested by Senator Baume, to prevent these people depriving our fishermen of a living not only in the short term but also in the long term because many of these areas will be fished out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point put forward by Senator McLaren is an interesting variation on the user pays principle. It might be termed the 'abuser pays principle'. He is suggesting that we should ensure that penalties imposed on these offenders are adequate to ensure recovery of costs. He points to the present case where, he says, there is a cost of apprehension of $9,000 and a fine imposed of $6,000. He asks: Does that really not show inadequate penalties? To some extent Senator McLaren answered the question himself because he also suggested that in the instant case the fisherman cannot pay, or may not be able to pay, and then faces a term of imprisonment of some six months. I suppose the consolation we have is that had he been fined $12,000 he might have faced a term of imprisonment of one year.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, if he cannot pay, the cost of imprisonment will be added to the very considerable costs of apprehension and, no doubt, of prosecution. So there is no guarantee that, simply by imposing a stiff monetary penalty, one will get to the position where there is a recovery of costs because, as in the example put forward by Senator McLaren in Committee today, it may well be that that simply increases ultimately the cost charged to the Australian taxpayer for care, maintenance and sustenance over a period of imprisonment. I do not have any recent figures as to the cost of imprisonment. Senator Evans, who used to take an interest in these matters, might have something he can contribute. I know that the cost is considerable. It is somewhere between the costs of being in an aged persons hostel and in a hospital. It is not cheap; and if imprisonment follows, undoubtedly there will be a considerable added impost to the taxpayer.

The answer provided in writing to the Estimates Committee following the questions asked by Senator Archer, with subsequent follow-up questions by Senator McLaren, about the costs of apprehension of a fishing vessel picked up the fact that revenue of $91,000 was obtained from the sale of two vessels, the Hwa Herng Nos 51 and 52, with this revenue being collected by the Department of Administrative Services. Notwithstanding that there were charges against that under other votes, it would appear that there is a substantial accrual to revenue in that particular transaction.

I think the final point I wish to make is simply that the Government, of course, is concerned that there should be adequate penalties in areas where they perhaps get historically out of date. I cannot say on the run whether there is that problem under the legislation that applies in these cases. I will refer Senator McLaren's suggestions to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and ask him to examine whether the penalties are adequate, given the seriousness of these offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the answer of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I think that it would be a cheap price to pay in the long run. With the imposition of more severe penalties and perhaps longer gaol terms the message might seep back to Taiwan of the treatment that these people will receive if they infringe our laws. The Minister has reminded me of the very severe penalties which are imposed in Thailand when Australians are caught trying to smuggle drugs out of that country. I think that the incidence of this is not as great now that the message has got through to young Australians that some of their countrymen are suffering very severe consequences and very long gaol sentences in Thailand. That is a good warning and a deterrent such as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, spoke about.

SPEECH.PARA: The same sort of penalty ought to be applied to these fishermen from Taiwan, and anywhere else for that matter, who poach in our waters. It is a very serious matter. If the average person were to pick up the newspaper and see the headline which I have quoted 'Taiwanese fisherman faces jail'-he was unable to pay a fine of $6,000-it would just go over his or her head because such a person is not interested in that aspect. But a lot of people are interested, particularly the people who make their livelihood out of fishing. That is something which we as members of parliament have to do all we can to protect. We have to protect the livelihood of those fishermen. At this stage I am talking only of fishermen. Now that the Minister has stated that what I have said will be drawn to the attention of the proper authorities, I hope that some action will be taken to overcome the problem with which fishermen, particularly in northern Australia, are faced. Every time one of these persons is apprehended, as we have been told, it costs about $9,000 to run them down. Then there are the court costs and, on top of that, the extra costs involved in keeping them in custody. The sooner we can put a stop to this the better.

Another matter which I wish to raise-my colleague Senator Walsh has referred to it-is the problem facing the canned fruit industry in South Australia, particularly in the Riverland area at Renmark. Over the years that I have been a member of this place, I have pleaded with the Government to liquidate some of the loans that were made to the canning industry in South Australia, which the Dunstan Labor Government did when it was in office, to help the growers over a stile. We were able to write off the loan and did not ask for it to be repaid. To my knowledge, despite my many pleas in this place, the Commonwealth Government has never been prepared to do that-not that it would have solved the problem which now faces the cannery at Berri. The cannery is in desperate trouble.

My State colleague Mr Brian Chatterton, a member of the Legislative Council in South Australia, who was the Minister of Agriculture prior to the 1979 election and is now the Opposition spokesman on primary industry, had a few pertinent comments to make this week. Yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser reports Mr Chatterton as follows:
'The IAC should not confine its enquiry just to growers,' he said.

'If there is going to be a reduction in canned fruits production in Australia this will mean a reduction in cannery throughputs which will affect cannery workers and the rest of the community who are dependent on their spending.'

There are many local people in the Riverland area of South Australia who depend on employment by the Riverland cannery. If this cannery ceases operation, there will be desperate problems. The Department of Social Security-Senator Chaney's Department-will be called upon to find a great deal of money to allow these people even to exist. The Advertiser went on to report:
Mr Chatterton said he was worried that a lot of growers were pinning their faith on a tree-pull scheme to resolve their problems.
'I don't think this alone is the answer,' he said.
'While there does not at present appear to be any future for many growers to continue producing canning fruit, there is also very little room for them in other traditional horticultural industries.'
'Just helping them to pull out trees would not restore their properties to commercial viability'.

He said the Federal Government's decision to delay consideration of assistance until late next year would impose heavy strains on growers and cannery workers, who had been told on Monday by the Australian Canning Fruit Corporation of heavy cuts in fruit intake this season, and a probable 50 per cent surplus of unsold fruit as a result.

That problem will be compounded by the situation that now exists in South Africa. Yesterday at a rural Press Club meeting, I happened to sit beside a South African. He told me that his country has problems of over production and declining markets. Therefore, having been told that and knowing the problems that we face locally, it does not appear to me that the canned fruit growers of South Australia have a very rosy future. Possibly the same situation faces fruit growers in the Shepparton area of Victoria. As Mr Chatterton said, even if the Government refers this matter to the Industries Assistance Commission it will be well into next year before the Commission makes any recommendations and an even longer period before any such recommendations could be implemented. Therefore, I hope that the Government is forewarned about the problem that exists. The Government created difficulties in the South Australian Riverland, for wine grape growers in particular, when it increased massively the excise on brandy, raising it to a level of 83 per cent. Many hundreds of growers in that area are still suffering the effects of that impost. As I said recently, when we were dealing with the report of the Australian Wine Board, the production of brandy in the Riverland of South Australia is at a very low ebb. That is a problem in itself. People who were growing grapes for the manufacture of brandy suffered a severe blow as a result of the level of excise being increased to 83 per cent. The Government subsequently reduced that figure by 3 1/2 per cent or 4 per cent and its supporters went round the country claiming that it had reduced the excise on brandy. They did not explain that the Government had first raised the level to 83 per cent. Some tried to explain away that action by stating that there had been a savage increase in brandy excise when the Whitlam Government was in office. Any such increase was not so severe as to put any grower off his block or to place him in a desperate financial situation. However, when a massive, additional increase occurs and the level is raised to 83 per cent, a real problem occurs.

Also, many of those who are affected are mixed growers. They produce not only grapes but also fruits for canning such as apricots and peaches, and are now to be faced with another problem. Also, the cannery workers face the loss of their jobs. If that happens it will have an effect on the small business people in the Riverland. Thus, we face a very chaotic and serious situation. I hope that the Government takes some note of what has been said, especially by Senator Walsh earlier and by me in repeating what my colleague in South Australia, Mr Chatterton, has said, and that remedial action will be taken to ease the suffering of the residents of the Riverland of South Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING: REPORT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 August 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Committee of the Whole, having considered the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing-
(a) endorses the conclusions of the Committee as summarised on pages (viii) and (ix) of its Report;
and in relation to the recommendations of the Committee on page (ix) of the Report-
(b) resolves that the Senate should establish a Standing Committee to consider the Senate's appropriations and staffing;

(c) calls on the Government to agree that the appropriations for the Parliament be removed from the Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government and included in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill;

(d) agrees that the expenditure administered by the Executive departments on behalf of the Parliament be brought together in a Parliamentary Appropriation Bill and that provision be made for an Advance to the President of the Senate on the same basis as the Advance to the Minister for Finance;

(e) directs that the President arrange for discussions to be held with the appropriate Executive departments to review those functions which are currently administered by them, and subsequently to plan the transfer of functions suitable for administration by the Senate; and

(f) agrees that section 9 of the Public Service Act 1922 be amended to vest in the Presiding Officers, separately or jointly as the case may be, the power of appointment, promotion, creation, abolition and reclassification of offices, and the determination of rates of pay and conditions of service.
(2) That the foregoing Resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message.

On 29 June this year, Senator Douglas McClelland, the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, and I released the report of the Committee. For many years now honourable senators and honourable members on both sides of the Senate and House of Representatives chambers have been concerned that to fulfil and maintain its function properly, the Parliament should make such arrangements as are necessary to achieve its proper constitutional relationship with the Executive, in practice as well as in theory. Indeed, the Select Committee discovered that a common source of concern to most parliaments throughout the world was the growing imbalance in the relationship between Parliament and the Executive, the rapidly increasing power and influence of the Executive, the need for Parliament to strengthen its oversight and check of Executive activity, and the concurrent need for the Parliament to regain or assert greater independence and autonomy in regard to its own internal arrangements.

The Senate first drew attention to this matter as long ago as 1965, and the report of the Select Committee traces the history since then. That history shows widespread concern that has continued unabated to the present day. It has, for example, been almost a recurring theme of the reports of Senate Estimates Committee A. The report of the Select Committee now gives the Senate a chance to do something about the matter.

The Select Committee recognised that the present constitutional arrangements place financial initiative firmly in the hands of the Executive and concluded that this is a proper arrangement for Government appropriations, but not for the appropriations for the Parliament. The arrangement which best recognises the relationship between the Parliament and the Executive is for the appropriations for each House to be contained in a separate amendable Bill which would not require a Governor-General's message and which would be capable of introduction in either House. This arrangement would underpin the independence of the Parliament and yet would still allow the Executive the opportunity to influence each House's appropriations on the floor of the respective chambers. I think that is an important point to remember. The Committee has not, of course, suggested that the machinery to amend the Constitution be now put in motion. However, a proposal to seek such an amendment could well be added to other proposals when the occasion next arises. In the meantime, and within the limitations imposed by the Constitution, it is still possible to make new arrangements to achieve a desirable measure of autonomy for the Parliament.

The Committee has recommended that the appropriations for the Parliament be removed from the Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government and included in a separate Appropriation Bill. In addition, it has recommended that each House establish a committee, with provision for representation of the Executive, charged with the task of examining the parliamentary estimates and agreeing to them with or without modification prior to their inclusion in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill. This arrangement produces both a desirable level of autonomy for the Parliament and also preserves the Government's examination from the standpoint of its budgetary policy. The Select Committee's investigation concerning staffing confirmed the cause for alarm which has been expressed in the past. The administrative procedure imposed by government has meant that, without the agreement of the Public Service Board, a staffing proposal has virtually no chance of approval by the Executive Council. The history of the debate surrounding this matter shows that the Senate, in particular, believes that the Board is not qualified in matters concerning staffing of the Parliament to be given what virtually amounts to a power of veto over the Parliament's proposals. It was partly with the problems of staffing the Parliamentary departments in mind that the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration developed proposals for the enactment of common legislation to cover Commonwealth employment generally. The Royal Commission stated that Parliament might consider the appropriateness of taking advantage of the provisions it had proposed so that the two Houses could apply the main features of Commonwealth employment to the parliamentary service, while reserving, for special determination by each House power to develop particular features.

The Public Service Board's submission to the Committee concluded with a list of features that a possible revision of Parliament's control of its own staffing might include. The Select Committee endorsed the proposals with the exception of the suggestion that it be mandatory for the Presiding Officers to obtain and consider the advice of the Board on rates of pay and terms and conditions of service. To make this suggestion shows a disregard for the position of the Board in relation to the Parliament. The view of the Royal Commission is far more enlightened: That the Parliament should have access to the Public Service Board for advice whenever that was considered necessary or desirable by the Presiding Officer. The Select Committee has pointed out that these changes can be achieved by a simple amendment to the Public Service Act. For reasons of time I will not canvass the details of the other two recommendations. Suffice it to say that they complete a reasoned and responsible approach.

Despite the evidence that, in the majority of countries throughout the world, the respective parliaments and Executives have made arrangements which provide for real autonomy in relation to parliamentary appropriations and staffing, the Select Committee could understand that there may be a reluctance on the part of the Government to agree to an immediate total reform package. In addition, the House of Representatives may determine that in some areas, other arrangements may be more suitable for its administration. The Committee was mindful of the need for an experimental approach to be adopted in making any new arrangements for appropriations and staffing, especially in a bicameral parliament where there is a sharing of certain services such as the Library, the Reporting Staff and those areas administered by the Joint House Department. For these reasons the Committee believed that the Senate, and where appropriate the Government, should agree to a trial of the proposed arrangements. Mr Temporary Chairman, there is nothing radical or sinister about the Committee's recommendations. The United Kingdom has had similar arrangements in operation for three years; the United States of America has had similar arrangements in operation for 60 years and Canada has had similar arrangements in operation for 114 years. The report of the Select Committee points the way for the Senate, and ultimately the Parliament, to now achieve a real measure of independence and autonomy in regard to its appropriations and staffing.

If honourable senators have a good look at the number of witnesses that we examined during our inquiry they will observe that quite eminent people from outside this organisation who are interested in Parliament appeared. For example, I think Professor Reid worked within the precincts of this Parliament, in the House of Representatives, for a number of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve years.
—Twelve years. We were dignified by having present before our Committee the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sir Billy Snedden.
—First time ever.

—For the first time in history. This was a mark of the importance the titular head of the House of Representatives regarded the measures implicit in this Bill as having. The Speaker was a little misguided on one or two aspects. I pointed that out clearly in the Senate on the last occasion I referred to the matter.
—Not misguided but perhaps mistaken.

—Yes, I think the Speaker was talking about single line appropriations. We do not suggest that. We have a model Bill that provides for an appropriate line dealing with various estimates of the different parts of this Parliament. Those particular lines in the Estimates would be subject to dissection and examination by the Senate as a whole. All honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives would be able to scrutinise the various elements within the administrative control of the Senate and the House of Representatives. There is nothing to fear in the Committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be interesting to the Senate to know that as part of my education in the methods being adopted overseas I journeyed to Canada and the United Kingdom. Senator Missen had a private consultation with the Speaker of the House of Commons when he was out here a year or two ago. The system is working well in the United Kingdom and it is working well in Canada. The secretary to the Committee, Mr Peter Murdoch, with our research officer, Mr Cleaver Elliot, have been magnificent in providing the research necessary for the Committee. I pay a tribute to them for the work they have done. As a matter of courtesy I instructed the secretary to forward copies of the report to the Parliament of Canada. I think the Committee can feel quite proud of the fact that the administrative officer or the Speaker of the Canadian Parliament requested an additional 24 copies of that document. Perhaps the example we have set in this report may well be emulated by the Canadian Parliament. Though it has persisted with a system such as this for 114 years I believe it can learn something in this regard from the Senate Select Committee report. I was able to speak with the administrative officers and Deputy Speaker of the Parliament in the United Kingdom. Unfortunately, the Speaker of the Parliament was not present at the time I was there. He had Asian flu or something of that nature and was on sick leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —He just heard you were coming.

—Well, I do not know about that. That Parliament regards the Australian Senate as being quite significant compared with the House of Lords. It is quite anxious to learn something of the progressive move implicit in the document we are discussing tonight. After all, it is an historic document because nothing has happened since Federation to improve the position of the Parliament with respect to the important subject that we are discussing. I was encouraged to find that since 1978 the British House of Commons-the Westminster system that we occasionally claim to be the mother of this Parliament-has adopted a similar sort of system and it is working well. Certainly, in the first stages of the administrative changes there were some bugs associated with it. We would expect that to happen here. The Government may well have some reservations about some of the suggestions in the report. Senator McClelland, Senator Robertson, Senator Mason and I appreciate that. We want to demonstrate to the Government of Australia that we are unanimous in our intent to have this reform initiated and brought into effect. We think that it is appropriate for the Senate to demonstrate the example to the House of Representatives over a trial period. I believe that the House of Representatives will be anxious to do something about it. I see that my time is up. I have a letter from Senator Rae, who posed certain questions relating to the report, and a copy of my reply to his questions. I seek leave to incorporate those two letters in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion that has been moved by Senator Jessop. The Australian Labour Party was a party to the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. As one of the representatives of the Labor Party on that Committee, along with my friend and colleague Senator Robertson, I took part in the deliberations of the Committee. We heard the evidence and we deliberated on the Committee's recommendations. We now recommend the implementation of those recommendations. They are basically in accordance with the policy of the Labor Party on the future operations of the Senate. We believe that there is no reason why the proposals should not be implemented by the Parliament or, for that matter, by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard this report as one of the most important select committee reports that the Senate has considered in my service of nearly 20 years in this place. For the past two decades at least honourable senators on both sides of the Parliament have been fighting to preserve the supremacy of the Parliament over the Executive and the bureaucracy and to get the Executive and the bureaucracy to take some notice of the workings of Parliament. As I understand it-I do not profess to be a lawyer by any stretch of the imagination-certain constitutional issues are involved concerning the Parliament in these recommendations. I refer, firstly, to the form of the presentation of the annual Appropriation Bills. Included in the Budget Papers that Parliament considers each year when the Budget is brought down are two documents. One is the particulars of proposed expenditure relating to the ordinary annual services of the Government. The other document relates to the particulars of proposed provision for certain other expenditure. Put in the simplest possible way, as I understand it the purpose of the division of the annual appropriations into two or more Bills is to protect the powers of the Parliament. To appreciate this, note must be taken of section 53 of the Constitution, which provides that the Senate may not amend proposed laws appropriating moneys for the ordinary annual services of the government. If all appropriations were deemed to be for the purpose of the ordinary annual services of the Government, as I understand it, the Senate would have no power to amend appropriations and could only request the House of Representatives to make any such amendment. This, of course, was the subject of scrutiny that began long ago. My service in this place began 17 or 18 years ago when senators such as the then Senator Murphy of the Australian Labor Party and the then Senator Cormack of the Liberal Party of Australia were involved in this place.

Indeed, as I understand it, well before that, at the beginning of Federation at the turn of the century, the then Senate insisted that certain expenditure, such as that proposed for Federal works and buildings, should not be included in the Appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government, but that there should be a second Appropriation Bill. The Government of the day acceded to the then Senate's claim and the practice was adopted of including in the main Appropriation Bill only matters relating to expenditure for the other annual services of the Government which may be described as being, or may be related to, expenditure concerning the salaries of public servants and other general or ancillary matters. Appropriations for public works and for buildings were included, as they are still included, in a separate Bill-the second Appropriation Bill, which of course is subject to amendment by the Senate.

It was argued by the early Senate that only with that amending power could the Senate prevent a disproportionate amount of Commonwealth money from being appropriated for public works in certain States to the disadvantage of other States. That type of classification, as I understand it, was adopted from what is known as the South Australian Compact of 1857 and that is, I believe, the origin and the reason for the presentation today of two Appropriation Bills. But in 1964 the then Government senators-it was the same type of government then as is in existence today-in their report on the annual Appropriation Bills, which were tabled in the Senate and which the Senate endorsed, had this to say in paragraph 98:

During the 1964 debate in the Senate on the contents of the annual Appropriation Bills, it was questioned whether the Parliament was one of the services of the Government. It was suggested that it may be ordinary, it may be annual and that it may even be regarded as a service-but not a service of the Government. It was suggested that it was inconsistent with the concept of the separation of powers and the supremacy of the Parliament to treat the provision made for the Parliament as being an ordinary annual service of the Government.

The point was also made in the debate that the officers and staff of the Parliament were not officers and staff of the Government but were responsible to the Parliament. In respect of appropriations for the Parliament being included in the first Appropriation Bill-that is the Bill relating to the ordinary annual services of the Government-the then Senator Murphy, now His Honour Mr Justice Murphy of the High Court, had this to say in 1964:

The Officers and Staff of the Parliament are not officers and staff of the Government. These persons are responsible to the Parliament. Procedures may have been adopted and there may be definitions in acts which treat them differently, but that no more alters the true position than does the description of senators and members as employees in the Income Tax and Social Services Assessment Contribution Act.

I do not know how it came about at some previous time that such a definition got into the act in relation to senators and members, but sometimes these things happen. What has happened does not alter the position. Members and senators are not employees of any one. Certainly they are not employees of the Government. Neither are the officers of this Parliament employees of the Government. They are officers and staff of the Parliament, and the sooner the position is regularized the better. If there needs to be an amendment of procedures, regulations, or even of an act, the sooner the amendment is made the better so that the position can be clarified.

That was in 1964. Now the Senate Select Committee-a tripartite select committee, to use Senator Jessop's words-is endeavouring to implement the situation as Senator Murphy professed it to be in 1964. I know that the wheels of Government turn slowly but this, I suggest is a ridiculous situation. It makes one wonder what power, if any, the Parliament-in this case, the Senate-may have over its own destiny and where, if anywhere, the Parliament, or the nation believing in the concept of parliamentary democracy, may be headed. I have already quoted Senator Murphy of the Australian Labor Party in 1964. Senator Cormack, as he then was, of the Liberal Party-a distinguished former President of the Senate-in 1968 on this subject had this to say:

In other words, I would observe, just to make it clear, that in respect of the ordinary annual services of the Government, the Senate has no right of amendment but only the right of request. Yet, in dealing with its own housekeeping, its own integrity as a chamber in the bicameral system, the Senate itself, in relation to the appropriations which are required for the maintenance of the Senate as an institution of Parliament, has only the lightest of control.

The 1980 Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, which has been commonly referred to as the Jessop Committee, has again reached the not unexpected but inescapable conclusion that Parliament, as it exists today under the Appropriation Bill, is not an ordinary annual service of the Government. Such classification is inconsistent with the concept of the separation of powers and supremacy of parliament. The Committee has said that the arrangement which best recognises the proper relationship between Parliament and the Executive is for the appropriations for each House to be included in a separate Appropriation Bill and for provision to be made for an advance to the President of the Senate-dealing with the Senate only in this instance-on the same basis as the Advance to the Minister for Finance for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

We say that a flexible approach is required rather than the rigid, structured approach which is in operation at the moment and which the Parliament has been forced by government to wear, as it were, like a strait-jacket. We have said that a desirable level of autonomy will be achieved for the Parliament if, in addition to the separate Appropriation Bill, each House establishes a committee with Executive representation to examine and to modify, if necessary, the parliamentary estimates. Much time and effort has been put into guidelines for parliamentary budgeting on a national and international level, so that any excuse that the regulation or deregulation has to be explored simply will not wash. If the Government wants to take note of any evidence in that regard, I would suggest that it looks at the report of the Secretary-General of the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Bonn of 1978 and the report of the then Clerk of the Senate, Mr Odgers, when he attended that IPU meeting as a representative of the Parliament.

The strangling administrative procedures imposed by government have meant that any staffing proposal or change has little chance, if any, of obtaining approval. I suggest, as the Committee suggests, that it is highly ridiculous for non-elected people-officers of the Department of Finance, the Department of the Treasury and the Commonwealth Public Service Board-to have a power of veto over decisions of the Parliament, decisions that the Parliament may make for its fuller function and the fuller and effective function of the parliamentary committee system.

That brings me to the conclusions and recommendations of the Select Committee. The recommendations are set out at paragraph 6.5 of the Committee's report. As a first step we recommend that the Senate establish a standing committee to be known as the Senate appropriations and staffing committee. It is proposed that the Committee would be chaired by the President of the Senate and would comprise six other members-the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Executive; two other Government senators, presumably back benchers; the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and two other senators, not members of the Government. We suggest that the standing committee would be charged with responsibility for the consideration of the proposed estimates for the Senate and the consideration of staffing proposals affecting the Senate and its committees. As I said at the outset, the Australian Labor Party has considered the matter as a whole. Senator Robertson and I had the honour to represent our party on the Committee. We believe the recommendations and the proposals of the Committee are practical and are capable of implementation. They are embodied in the terms of Senator Jessop's motion. We give our support to the terms of the motion which was moved by him this evening. We support the proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this motion as a beginning to a process which we hope will free the Senate from the constraints now placed on it, and which have been placed on it for so long. The motion does not give the Senate the freedom of determining its own fate that we would like, especially with regard to its money appropriations. That point has been made by Senator Douglas McClelland. That is why we see this motion as a beginning. Later some honourable senators may care to propose amendments to what has been put before us. Frankly, any amendments I would be likely to move would be too radical for general acceptance at this stage, so I will leave it to somebody who perhaps appreciates the necessity for gradualism in this matter more than I do to do that. The Australian Democrats and I will look forward with great interest to the way in which this debate proceeds and what it reveals as it proceeds, particularly in relation to the viewpoint of the Government and the Executive-if we hear that expressed in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that the situation of many decades in which this House, the Senate, has been virtually held in a strait-jacket by the Executive must end, no matter how difficult and protracted that labour might be. The Senate is only now, the Australian Democrats believe, beginning to exercise the influence and significance it owes to the Australian people and which the architects of the Constitution intended. If those architects had expected this place to be a mere rubber stamp of the Executive they would have created something like the Canadian Senate, all the members of which are appointed by the Prime Minister of Canada, which is virtually nothing more than a pale imitation of the House of Lords-a very pale imitation. It is an establishment House; in particular, a business establishment House.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't carry on like this if you could win any seats in the Reps, would you?

—But that was not the intention. Our founding fathers created a House of virtually equal powers to the House of Representatives, elected by one of the most representative and enlightened voting systems in the world. The system is recognised as such. The vicious effects of the two party system have not, until recently, allowed the Senate to evolve along the lines of the House upon which it was so plainly modelled-that is the Senate of the United States of America, which is now, for very good reasons, a more important House than the House of Representatives. That is not to say that the Senate has all the powers of that House. Indeed, it has not. But I believe that certainly it was intended by the architects of the Constitution of this country to have considerably more power than it has exercised in the past. The question of the role of the Australian Senate and the extent to which it has not yet realised its destiny is highly relevant to this debate. Hence I would like to quote a little from a classic reference, Lindsay Roger's The American Senate, to point out some analogies. Rogers says that where there is a second, revising chamber it must have real authority. He continues, at page 90:

SPEECH.PARA: Two chambers of equal powers permit and even invite deadlocks. This is the price that the congressional system pays for an upper house that represents the States, and believers in throttling down the government machine will consider it a small price.

The effects of the United States Senate in refining and altering hastily put together legislation is very great. In one review of the tax laws the United States Senate proposed 833 amendments, all but seven of which were accepted by the United States House of Representatives. It is, I think, relevant that the Bill was debated in the House of Representatives for four days and in the Senate for six weeks. That is because the Senate is there regarded as the refining house for legislation. At page 118, Rogers says:

The voluntary submission of the House of Representatives to the Executive is increasing rather than diminishing. It profoundly affects the character of American government and adds greatly to the influence of the Senate.
There is an interesting quotation which I propose to cite to honourable senators in full because I think it contains a certain irony. It refers to the American House of Representatives and states:

The leaders of a legislative body must be able to have their programme acted upon, but to accomplish this there must be frequent curtailment of debate. Taciturnity is rarely a characteristic of a person chosen to represent constituents, and there is thus a fairly constant tendency for those who control the procedure of a legislative assembly to sacrifice discussion to their timetable and to deal more and more ruthlessly with the rights of their own followers and of opposing minorities. Changes of rules have had two principal objectives. They have been designed, in the first place, to make it certain that the majority steam-roller would proceed and not be stopped by the minority; and, secondly, to prevent the course of the steam-roller from being diverted through members of the majority venturing to repudiate the leaders and their programme. These two objectives are distinct. Rules of procedure which simply provide for expeditious and businesslike attention to Bills may be justified to the extent that they accomplish this purpose, while they become objectionable if, in limiting debate, they stifle deliberation and reduce the assembly to a position where it must act as a rubber stamp.
Later at page 132, Rogers states:
The House is kept from making a 'wrong' decision by being kept from making any decision except the one which the leaders desire it to make.

These words, which originally were written to justify the primacy of the United States Senate, have an ironic enough ring. I suggest that in many respects they could apply with increasing force to the Australian House of Representatives where indeed we see the Executive dominance virtually carried out par excellence. I complete the analogy with Rogers' words on page 161:
It is the willingness of the House of Representatives to be a rubber stamp that contributes so largely to the greater power of the Senate. The second chamber is really the first chamber.

It is interesting that that has happened in the world's largest and greatest democracy, one with which we in this place, all of us, would not see any great incompatibility. That is then, perhaps, how this country's legislature should evolve. Already I believe, in recent weeks, we have seen a greater questioning in this House of the powers of the Executive and a greater assertion of the powers of the Senate, an elected House of the people, to do that. Indeed that is a duty and responsibility of this House. It would be shirking that duty if it did not so act. That great task, which took in the United States many generations to achieve-the acknowledgment of the Senate as a House of genuine review of legislation-may also take some considerable time to achieve here. It will be achieved, as in the United States, to the extent that senators of integrity and dedication, who think beyond party, allow it to do so. Honourable senators who know the history of the United States Senate will know that my words describe exactly what has happened in that place over the decades and, indeed, centuries.

What then should we do in Australia? Should we see a similar situation arise here? Where has the problem been? I think that to some extent it has been due to an attempt to graft the Westminster system of the United Kingdom onto a political dynamic in Australia which is essentially foreign to it. The Westminster system suits the United Kingdom because the House of Lords is and always has been a thoroughly undemocratic House, positions to which are inherited or appointed by the Executive. That is not so in the Australian Senate. This is a freely elected House of great potential power; not power to make and break governments, or to block and obstruct. It is none of those things which are all bad, unconstructive and negative. It has power to do positive things-to guide, reform, amend and generally curb excesses and ill-judgments of the lower House if and when they should occur. I am not criticising the lower House in saying that. I am merely saying that it has been the experience of the world that first chambers with the competition, perhaps the short electoral terms and other pressures applied on them, sometimes tend to legislate hastily or, perhaps, not necessarily for all the motives that would be desired.

I and the Australian Democrats are thoroughly sick of this sort of weird cult that has grown up in Australia that the Senate is a kind of supernumerary House which blocks things. That is absolute rubbish. The Senate, granted the numbers, must extend its powers until they come closer in some respects-not all respects-to those of the United States Senate which it closely resembles in its basic character. The key mechanism of the United States Senate is worth looking at because it has a great relevance to what we are discussing at this time. It is the legislative committees to which virtually all Bills are referred which, as a machine of the United States Senate, have been so effective and so useful. A more recent authority than the one I quoted, Lindsay Rogers, is Dodd and Oppenheimer's Congress Revisited. It notes on page 16 that an ever increasing legislative work load has had a major impact on the Senate and that the committee staffs of roughly 300 in the eighty-fifth congress-that is, in 1957-58-had grown to over 1,000 committee staff by the ninety-fourth congress in 1975.

We note, on information that I have, that the Senate has 64 members as against the American Senate which has 100 or 102. Our committee staff numbers do not even approach 50. How can this House possibly exercise the powers which it properly should exercise and which it owes the people in terms of its mere existence? Dodd and Oppenheimer in their book note that the expansion of staff has allowed senators to cope more easily with more work and greater responsibilities. They noted the greater flexibility and pointed out that the previous situation where the committee chairmen dominated the appointment of staff in the 1970s had disappeared so that even deputy sub-committee chairmen had the right to hire and fire staff. Of course, the American Senate does have the right of its own appropriation and a complete right of its own hiring and firing of staff and control over the numbers of staff. It must justify that, of course, just as any other House must do to the electorate which will judge it on the work it has done compared with what it cost. It is wrong, iniquitous and improper that another House of parliament or the Executive should decide what a freely elected House should do in terms of, firstly, what it spends and, secondly, what staff it needs to do the work it believes it is prepared to carry out and which it sees as its responsibility.

The characteristics of the United States Senate are typified by its unwillingness to allow the gag or guillotining of debate even after the 1975 reforms of the closure or cloture rules as they are called. Three-fifths of all members of the Senate must vote to gag a debate. There is a very interesting quotation from Senator Mansfield which might interest honourable senators. He said:
You can get the closure when you have a case, but when you have a bill of goods to sell to the Senate, a bill of goods that is under suspicion and not in the national interest, it should not be sold.

I suggest that these are words which we, in this House, ought to take to heart. We might see something of our own duty in those words of a distinguished American senator. Page 11 of the Select Committee's report in relation to the United States states:.
The autonomy of the Senate and the House with regard to appropriations is reflected in the ability of both chambers to appoint staff as required.
With regard to committee staffs, there is a commitment and an acceptance of the need to match the expanding government programmes and expenditures with increased staffing levels.

The Senate is having increasing numbers of select committees. If we are to have those select committees it is our duty and responsibility to carry out the tasks effectively. How can we do the work of those committees effectively when the Executive, which may not necessarily agree with its legislation being referred to select committees, or any matters being referred to select committees, says: 'No. We will retain the right to say that you will be starved of money. We will retain the right to say that you cannot have more than a certain staff ceiling'. Surely it must be the other way round? Once this House has taken on a certain amount of work, surely it must decide what staff it will need.

The general idea that an independent equal house of parliament elected by the people should be hamstrung in its work by staff ceilings-as a Public Service department is-or, indeed from lack of funds, is absurd. It is like saying: 'You will economise'-I know that economy might be brought forward as a point in this matter-'in a railway network by buying no locomotives'. It is obvious that there has to be control over funding. But, as with many other things, it should eventually and ultimately be a matter between this Senate and the electorate. It would depend also on the amount of value which the electorate placed upon the Senate.

The basic point is that the Senate has a role to perform; it has to take a second cool look at law. An executive government in a modern democracy, I think, should be willing to recognise and concede the rightness of that role. It should not obstruct it and should not say to the Senate that it is a blocker if it does or says anything whatsoever which might not suit the Executive. But it should assist that process in the cause of a proper and reasonable advancing democracy in this country. I end with a quote from Measure for Measure. What Lindsay Rogers very wisely said legislators everywhere, I think, should remember is this:
Oh! It is excellent
To have a giant's strength, but it is tyrannous
To use it like a giant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting the recommendations in the report of the Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. As a member who is engaged in the deliberations of this Committee, I can say only that the report 'Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing' is one which has my full support. I believe that it is necessary for the Senate to take action-I hope with the co-operation of the Government-to secure some situation, as far as the financing and staffing of the Senate is concerned, on a par with similar houses of parliament in other parts of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight, a number of honourable senators have spoken of the situation in Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States of America which examples were studied during the course of this inquiry. It is clear, it has been accepted and it has been said-sometimes for a 150 years or more-that appropriations ought to be determined by the house of parliament knowing what are its needs and in which direction it wants to go. The appropriations should not be determined by a government or, as is more often the case, by public servants who make recommendations and decide that such and such is the appropriate amount for that house of parliament.

Of course, it can be said that this is not one of the ordinary annual services of the Government. I think this has already been said tonight. But I remind honourable senators of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in June 1976. This was a report on the ordinary annual services of the Government. We referred there, of course, to the agreement-the compact, as it is known-of 1965 following a report by a committee of Government senators under the chairmanship of the then Senator Cormack. Subsequently his committee's report became Parliamentary Paper No. 55 of 1967.
In the summary of the Committee's recommendations is the following very simple statement:
(6) Parliament-Appropriations for the purposes of Parliament should not be included in the Appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

That, of course, was agreed to by the then Government. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended that that compact be affirmed. The Committee corresponded with the then Treasurer, Sir Phillip Lynch, who confirmed the acceptance of the compact in these terms:

I am aware of the terms of the 1965 compact and confirm that there is no present intention of seeking a change in its terms, i.e., we propose to follow it in the preparation of future appropriation legislation.

There had, of course, been some criticism by Estimates committees and others of aspects of the Appropriation Bills. But the Government has confirmed that it accepts that view. It is important that neither House of Parliament be treated as one of the ordinary annual services of the Government. Parliament is not a service of the Government; it is a separate part of the administration in this country.

I think the questions included in this report in regard to staffing are important but the appropriation matters are even more important. One is supplementary to the other. A very important issue that must be considered is not just a question of whether the Senate, which has a committee to determine what its needs are, should determine how it will be paid and what moneys will be needed for each of its separate organisations; but of course the total amount-the global figure as it is sometimes called-to be paid for Parliament must be determined. Is this to be a figure which, on the recommendations of the Senate organisation, needs to be higher this year? Should it be in the hands of the Government to determine that it be chopped back? I think that is an important question in this whole issue. Unfortunately the motion we have before us does not include that question. At the end of my speech I will move to adjourn the debate tonight because it is my opinion that the motion, both in its preamble and in its body, needs a specific reference to that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adjourn it for how long, Senator?

—We have received undertakings that his matter can come on next week for further debate. Consequently, I feel it would be very desirable in the next few days to have the opportunity both of fixing up the motion and also of discussing this matter further with the Government. As all honourable senators know, discusions have been held and suggestions made. At the moment there is some lack of clarity as to exactly where we are going. To demonstrate the point I make, I point out that honourable senators will see in the motion these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee of the Whole, having considered the Report . . .-
(a) endorses the conclusions of the Committee summarised on pages (viii) and (ix) of its Report.
In that section of the report there are some references to this question, but only in an oblique way and only in relation to what is wrong with the present system. Conclusion 4 states:
In the meantime-
That is, after we have put the constitutional arrangements on a better footing--
it is still possible to make new arrangements to achieve a desirable measure of autonomy for the Parliament . . .
So there is a reference to autonomy, and that means control over money matters. Conclusion 5 states:

The present procedure for Parliament's appropriations is unsatisfactory as it involves Parliament making bids about which the Executive may apply a qualitative judgement and thereby restrict the ability of the Legislature to discharge its constitutional duties . . .

That obviously suggests that we should be setting out some other system which is not based on bids but in which a determination is made by the Parliament; but the conclusions do not go on to talk about that. That matter is dealt with in chapter 6. The Committee's recommendation 6.8, which describes how a Senate appropriations and staffing committee would work, reads:

In relation to the Estimates, the Committee would examine the proposals of the President and the officers of the Senate at, unless otherwise ordered, public hearings. The Estimates as finally agreed by the Committee would be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill. The Minister would then introduce the Bill in the House of Representatives in accordance with current practice. The Senate, upon receipt of the Bill from the House of Representatives, would consider its provisions in the normal way and, at that time, would also have before it a report from the Appropriations and Staffing Committee covering its deliberations concerning the Estimates.

There is an indication in that quotation that it is intended that the expenditures recommended by the Committee to be set up would be included in the separate parliamentary Bill. To make the position quite clear, paragraph 6.9 of the report states:

Should the Government of the day be opposed to any of the Estimates as agreed to by the Committee and included in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill, it has the opportunity (on matters affecting the Senate) to seek amendments in the Bill during the Committee of the Whole stage on the floor of the Senate.

I think it is clear from the recommendations that it is intended by the Committee that that important aim should be achieved. As the evidence set out in the Committee's report shows, in practically all parliaments around the world the determination of these things are done essentially by committees and not, as has been the case in Australia for many years, by the Executive government. I think that is consequently a very important part to be included in the resolutions that the Committee shall adopt. In his speech in support of the motion, Senator Jessop obviously had this very much in mind because he said:

In addition, it has recommended that each House establish a committee, with provision for representation of the Executive, charged with the task of examining the parliamentary estimates and agreeing to them with or without modification prior to their inclusion in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bill.

That seems, of course, to accord with the recommendation of the Committee but unfortunately it is not yet in the motion before the Chair. Consequently, supporting the motion as I do and feeling that this is a matter that desirably must be pressed forward by the Parliament, and by this House in particular, I think we should put the matter in a perfectly sound and accurate manner. Therefore, I think it would be wise if we had a few days in which to tidy up the details of the motion. It is for this reason that I have spoken to the Opposition parties because we are assured that this matter can come back for debate next week.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November 1981 (on motion by Senator Missen):

(1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, be appointed to report, in respect of the clauses of Bills introduced into the Senate, and in respect of Acts of the Parliament, whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise-
(i) trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(ii) make rights, liberties and obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers or non-reviewable administrative decisions; or
(iii) inappropriately delegate legislative power or insufficiently subject its exercise to parliamentary scrutiny.

(b) That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting upon the clauses of a Bill when the Bill has been introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.

(2) (a) That the Committee consist of six Senators, three being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and three being Senators who are not members of the Government, to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators shall be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee shall be determined by the Senate.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That three members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers.

(8) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(9) That the Committee be empowered to appoint with the approval of the President counsel to advise the Committee.
(10) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion, brought on earlier in the week, was moved by Senator Missen and seconded by Senator Tate. My colleague, Senator Chaney, commenced to handle it on behalf of the Government. Unfortunately, he cannot be present this evening. Therefore, I do not know whether I need to seek leave to take his place and continue the debate on behalf of the Government.
—I will regard you as having been seen and called, Mr Attorney.

—Thank you, Mr President. In any event, it is in fact a matter for which I have responsibility on behalf of the Government and Senator Chaney was handling it on the other occasion in my absence. The matter, as far as the Government is concerned, is my responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter, of course, has received a good deal of consideration already from honourable senators in that it was the subject of recommendations by a Senate committee to which I responded on behalf of the Government some time ago. The reasons that were given by the Government to oppose the establishment of another standing committee of the Senate for the specific purpose as outlined in Senator Missen's motion were set out in that earlier response. The arguments that have been advanced by Senator Missen and Senator Tate in support of the motion are ones which, without any disrespect to those arguments, were considered by the Government and members of this chamber during the previous debate. Indeed, wide discussion has taken place on this matter for some time. Therefore, I do not think I ought to detain the Senate at any great length this evening in responding to this motion.

As Senator Chaney already has said, the Government is opposed to the motion because it does not believe there is a case for a special consideration of these matters either by any of the existing committees or by the establishment of a new committee. In the Government's view there are already ample opportunities for the examination of legislation that comes before the Parliament to ensure that human rights and civil liberties are protected and that any provisions which might be objectionable on these scores are brought to the Parliament's attention.

I would just like to recapitulate the processes by which these matters are attended in the development of legislation. I will then move to the record this Senate in particular has in dealing with matters of this kind. I think we would all agree that the question of legislation infringing basic human rights or civil liberties is a most important one that should be in the minds of all members of parliament when they consider legislation. We would all agree that legislation ought to be passed in such a form that there is not any undue invasion of these rights. I think that in fact is the phraseology of the motion. It does not say that legislation cannot trespass sometimes on rights or liberties. Obviously a lot of legislation does restrict liberties and existing rights. It is important to note that Senator Missen's motion simply requires consideration of whether legislation trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulations and ordinances one, too.

—Yes, I appreciate that. But I want to make that point because I do not think we ought to be deluding ourselves into thinking that somehow or other we are going to be able to protect absolutely rights and liberties because that simply is not consistent with a great deal of legislation that for various good reasons is passed by parliaments and proposed to parliaments by members of all political parties and all governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Both sides of this Parliament are on common ground in the belief that there should be very good reasons before legislation is allowed to restrict liberties or existing rights. Such legislation should be passed only if there are good reasons to do so. In the process of formulating legislation these matters are, in fact, well within the mind and attention of government and its advisors. The processes begin, I suppose, even during the period of getting instructions for legislation to parliamentary counsel. I can assure the Senate that parliamentary counsel are particularly alert to these questions. From my experience as Attorney-General I know that in the drafting process they draw these questions to my attention and no doubt to that of other people if they feel that the instructions they have provide an undue trespass on these matters.

Before the legislation is ever presented to Parliament it is looked at by a legislation committee of Cabinet. Under a system which has been in existence for some time, legislation goes to the back bench party committees on the Government side and when it is introduced it goes to similar Opposition committees. There is now built into the system, both at the government level and at the parliamentary level, every opportunity, I believe, for a close examination of legislation even before it is debated in the Parliament. In the House of Representatives a number of Bills now go to the legislation committees. Debate which would have taken place in the Committee of the whole now takes place in a committee atmosphere which is perhaps more conducive to consideration of these matters than the set piece second reading debate. Probably most importantly of all we have provision in the Senate for the consideration of many Bills in detail in the Committee stage. I think that the Senate has established over the years a very high reputation for having regard to these matters and giving particular attention to them. Over the years matters of this kind have been raised time and again in the Senate and many amendments have been made to legislation because these matters have been raised by honourable senators in debate on the floor of this chamber.

The point I am making is that there are, in fact, a great many opportunities for these matters to be considered in the process of developing legislation and its consideration before debate in the Parliament and during debate in the Parliament. Not only are there these opportunities but also these opportunities are, in fact, made extensive use of by senators and members. The Senate has, I think, developed a high reputation for the work that it has done in being a watchdog on these questions. In the Government's view there is no necessity at all for a special committee to take on the responsiblity of examining these questions.

Apart from that, I believe that it is invidious for the Parliament to establish committees to do this. It seems to me that questions of this kind should be the responsibility of at least a number of senators and members, if not all senators and members. In fact, as I have said, there have always been a number of senators who have taken a particular interest in looking at legislation with regard to these questions. I believe that that responsibility should continue to be exercised by senators. There should not be this idea that it is the responsibility of a few senators on a committee to look at these questions. I think we devalue the role of senators, in particular, if we give any support to the view that these matters should be shunted off to a committee and that senators themselves should not continue to bear a direct and personal responsibility for these questions when the Bills are being debated in the Committee stage.

Other matters have been put forward by the Government. One is that the process of having a special committee look at these matters could be a means of unduly delaying the passage of legislation. I know that the motion proposed by Senator Missen does not build in any particular road blocks, as such; nevertheless the fact that a committee would be looking at these matters undoubtedly would have an effect on when legislation would be dealt with. It may be said: 'We have not yet had a report from the scrutiny of Bills committee on this Bill; we cannot go on and debate it because the committee has not looked at it'.The committee may have a great many matters on its plate and it may not be in a position to get around to considering a particular Bill before the Senate for other reasons wishes to get on with a consideration of it. I do not place the same importance on that argument as I do on the first argument I mounted. Nevertheless, I think it is an important consideration. I agree that the Senate could at any time ignore those questions; nevertheless I am sure that if a committee of this type were set up there would be some further delay in the process of the passage of legislation.

There is another argument which ought to be put. I do not know that I actually spelt it out in my previous response. It would be difficult to isolate one's judgment about these questions from the Bill as a whole and the policy and social purpose of it. Obviously these questions, in the end, are decided by the Parliament in relation to the whole Bill as well as the questions of policy that I have mentioned. I do not think it is feasible to judge whether some provision unduly trespasses on rights or liberties without having regard to the whole policy. I know that that still would be a matter for the Senate to determine in the end. The fact of the matter is that a standing committee of the Senate, considering these matters in isolation, undoubtedly would have quite an influence in the Senate debate and perhaps, unfortunately, an undue influence. It might divert attention from the consideration of the Bill as a whole. The Senate's exercise in Committee is to look at the Bill as a whole or clause by clause, but its consideration is not divorced from the purposes of the Bill or the policies behind it.

Although we ought to be always alert-I think we are alert-to the effect of a Bill on personal rights, civil liberties and such matters, in the end a judgment has to be made in regard to the social purpose behind the Bill. I think that to isolate it in the way proposed is a wrong way of looking at it. The whole Bill may be said to be largely dealing with personal rights and liberties. I instance the Criminal Investigation Bill, which I introduced into the Senate yesterday. It would seem quite inappropriate to have a Bill such as that considered by the proposed committee. All the questions that arise in the Bill deal with personal rights and how they are protected, matters of investigation by the police and so on. A number of Bills of that kind are presented in Parliament. It would seem to be quite inappropriate for a Bill of that sort to be dealt with in one committee whereas its policy considerations may need to be looked at by another committee and when in fact the ultimate consideration of the Bill will be given in the Committee of the Whole after the second reading debate.

I believe that many practical problems may emerge if this committee is set up. For all these reasons the Government is opposed to it. As I have said, the Government is opposed only to these matters being considered in the way that is proposed in the motion. It is not, of course, in any way to be taken to be opposed to the need for very alive and earnest consideration to be given to questions of such great importance as those relating to the personal rights and civil liberties of people affected by legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that this is the second debate that we have had tonight which deals with the rights of the Senate and its position in relation to the Executive. I think this is an area to which we have to give a great deal more attention in the future because this is one of the great problems confronting the developing Westminster system in all countries. I, like the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), am disappointed that Senator Chaney could not be here tonight to conduct a spirited campaign in favour of the Government's rejection of a scrutiny of Bills committee. It would be very difficult for him to do so, seeing that as a back bencher he was the originator of the idea, but I am sure that he would have struggled nobly to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General gave us in answer substantially the same reply he gave two years ago when rejecting the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for the establishment of a joint committee of both Houses of Parliament to scrutinise Bills. The trouble is that the case presented is, in my view, a defective one. The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee proposed that a joint committee be set up to examine all Bills in much the same way as the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances examines subordinate legislation to see that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, that it provides an adequate review of administrative powers and decisions and that it does not unduly delegate legislative powers without proper parliamentary scrutiny.

The role of the Committee-I think the Attorney-General misunderstood the role as I envisage it anyway-would merely be to draw the attention of the Parliament to apparent breaches of these principles so that they could be debated. In the case of the Criminal Investigation Bill, which the Attorney-General cited, I imagine that the scrutiny of Bills committee would merely draw the whole Bill to the attention of the Parliament. It has to see that these things do not slip through unnoticed. The role of the committee in relation to Bills such as the Criminal Investigation Bill would be almost superfluous. There would be no need for the committee to draw such a Bill to the attention of the Senate because we would all be well aware of and would have all these aspects in mind. I do not think that would be a large task for the committee. I think it would be one with which it could deal in about 10 seconds. It could just commit the whole Bill to the attention of the Senate as one that had potential areas of conflict concerning personal rights and liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you guarantee that that is all it would do?

—If it did more than that I would be greatly opposed to its actions. Its job would not be to express opinions or make concluded judgments. It should merely say: 'This is an area at which the Senate should look'. I think that to do any more than that would be improper. That would be the committee's role. I do not think it should go further. By the way, it was also realised by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee that factors other than those listed should sometimes be involved and that it might sometimes be necessary on balance to accept restrictions on personal rights and liberties, but at least Parliament should make such a decision with its eyes open.

SPEECH.PARA: In giving the Government's reasons for rejecting the Committee's proposal the Attorney-General said that the present parliamentary procedures provide ample opportunity for the necessary scrutiny. He went on to list the opportunities. The first two he listed were consultation between the Parliamentary Counsel and the Department concerned, and consideration by the Cabinet Legislation Committee. Both points are, with respect, totally irrelevant to the issue we are debating. We are not talking about the Executive's scrutiny of itself. We are talking about parliamentary scrutiny of the Executive; an entirely different matter.

The Attorney-General also referred to the Legislation Committees of the House of Representatives. I do not want to cast too many adverse judgments on their performance but one thing is quite clear and that is that they are not effective for this role. They look at only a very small proportion of the legislation that is passed by the House of Representatives. What we want is a committee that will draw the attention of the Parliament to obscure Bills, the ones that pass unnoticed, perhaps are even scarcely debated, not the contentious ones.
