The contentious ones are looked at. It is the small Bills that are liable to contain provisions that may subsequently be found to be objectionable.

The Attorney-General, in his earlier statement of two years ago-he repeated some of the same words this evening-went on to argue that the Bills are examined closely and with the principles the Senate Committee is concerned with very much in mind in the traditional Senate Committee debate. I think this is absolute nonsense. Traditional Senate debates do no such thing. How could they? We sometimes pass 30 or 40 Bills a week. For the Senate to perform the role the Attorney-General apparently thinks it already does would require a radical restructuring of Senate procedures on lines I have advocated both inside and outside this chamber but which I understand the Government still opposes. The Attorney-General then said in his original statement:

. . . the law and Government Committee of the Government parties is invited to give close scrutiny to legislation that may raise questions in the light of the principles that the Senate Committee proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that tonight though.

—No, he did not repeat it tonight. I said that he said it in the statement two years ago. As we pointed out at the time, that statement is not true. That Government Committee has not, never has had and still does not have any such role. Senator Missen's motion would set up a new Senate standing committee to perform this scrutiny role. Before we take such a step, for a new committee would tend to have an indefinite life of its own, I think the Senate should have a chance to judge how useful the new committee system would be from practical experience. What we should do, therefore, is to conduct an experiment, after which we could judge whether we wish it to continue. It may be-I do not think it is-that the Government is right that the present procedures are adequate and a new committee would turn up nothing new. Let us find out before we take the extreme and fairly permanent step of setting up a new standing committee. Rather than setting up a new committee, I think we should refer the scrutiny task to one of our existing committees for a trial, and I will be moving to this effect in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: For a committee to perform this scrutiny function I suggest it needs a regular meeting date, a membership which contains some legal expertise, and a permanent legal counsel who would have the responsibility of examining all Bills as soon as they are introduced and promptly drawing the Committee's attention to any suspect areas. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances meets these criteria. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs sets out the arguments in favour of using the Regulations and Ordinances Committee for this scrutiny of Bills role, but finally comes down against this solution because scrutiny of principal legislation, as that Committee put it, 'would constantly overshadow the scrutiny of delegated legislation' and, as it goes on to say, it might 'overload the Committee to such an extent that their existing work would be imperilled'. Although I think this exaggerates the amount of work involved and although I think the Regulations and Ordinances Committee will ultimately be found to be the most suitable body to do this scrutiny task, in view of these remarks I do not think we should burden this Committee with this role until we have some idea of the size of the task we propose to give it.

Some time ago I asked for a survey to be made of a typical period to get an idea of how many Bills a legal counsel might bring to the attention of a scrutiny of Bills committee. A list, prepared by the staff of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee has been circulated to senators. It covers the Bills passed during 1980. It listed 80 queries on 31 Bills. I think it probably overstates the work load. Twenty-six of the queries related to discretions given to the Commissioner of Taxation. There is a very elaborate appeal procedure against the Commissioner's decisions. I do not think the Senate or the scrutiny of Bills committee will be likely to want to remove his discretions. But even assuming that the list is representative, the Committee would be required to consider only an average of two or three Bills a sitting week to determine whether there were any aspects of sufficient importance to justify reference to the Senate by merely drawing the attention of the Senate to the fact that there was a possible problem here, expressing no concluded view, just drawing the Senate's attention to a possible problem area. This does not seem to me to be an excessive work load.

The question is: Who should do the trial? The Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee raised this issue and is, I understand, prepared to conduct a trial. I propose, therefore, that the members of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee should be the scrutiny of Bills committee for a trial six months period during which they could assess the work load involved and report to the Senate on this work load. We, all of us senators, could assess the value to us of having our attention drawn to possible breaches of the scrutiny criteria. Then we could decide whether or not we wish to set up a permanent organisation to scrutinise Bills and, if so, who should do it. I move:
After paragraph 9, insert the following new paragraph:

9. (a) That notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, the members of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs be the members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills until the thirtieth day of June 1982 and that, prior to that time, the said Committee report to the Senate on the work of the Committee and the need, if any, for a separately constituted Standing Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion, Mr Acting Deputy President. In so doing, I would like to say briefly that the Australian Democrats are attracted to the notion of the scrutiny of bills coming into this place in relation to undue violation of human rights. The problem that we had with it I think is amply satisfied by the suggestions of Senator Hamer in that we were concerned at the practicality of the matter and feel that the method of sending it to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should, indeed, enable us to have a fair and adequate estimation of what might happen, or what might be seen to be happening in future to a committee which has to undertake a task such as this. We believe that by allowing the Bills in the autumn session to undergo this type of scrutiny by the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, that Standing Committee will be well placed at the time set down in the motion of Senator Hamer to advise the Senate on the need, if any, for a separate standing committee. I believe that in this way we are able to accept the principle and also to test the practicality. It is an admirable compromise and we support it whole-heartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one can actually accuse the Parliament of rushing headlong into the change that is embodied in Senator Missen's motion tonight. It is three years now since the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommending this kind of change was brought down. Indeed, I now find that there are something like four previous occasions on which I have addressed the Senate in support of this matter. The accumulated canon can be found in Hansard on 23 November 1978, 1 March 1979, 22 November 1979 and again on 6 March 1980. I do not propose to repeat the arguments which I advanced at nauseous length on all those previous occasions. I simply make the point that we are dealing here with what is clearly a significant innovation into the practice and procedure not only of this chamber but also of this Parliament, an innovation which should improve and enhance the quality and, in many ways, the legitimacy of all the legislation which is in fact passed by this Parliament, whichever party is in power. The reality, as all of us are only too well aware, is that there is far too little effective scrutiny not so much of the policy of Bills but of the details of Bills that pass through our hands.

SPEECH.PARA: Under these circumstances it is really quite extraordinary that there has been so much opposition expressed by the Government. I put it to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), as the representative of the Government, that there is really no need for the kind of nervousness demonstrated here tonight and indeed over the events of recent weeks and months-in fact the last three years-when one looks at the very limited role it is proposed that the Committee in practice will play. In this respect I will repeat-I will do so in no more than a sentence-the points that have been made so amply and adequately by Senator Missen, Senator Hamer and Senator Tate. What is proposed is simply that the Committee look at the detail of legislative proposals which might otherwise not be subject to scrutiny by reference to these particular civil liberty and excessive delegation criteria. That is what is involved here; that is the way the Committee will operate. There is simply no reason for the kind of nervousness about an intrusion into governmental prerogatives which seems to have been advanced here tonight.

The reason for the Government's resistance to this matter seems essentially to be psychological. This Government really does prefer rhetoric to reality when it comes to human rights matters. It feels much more comfortable when it is merely talking about the majesty of the common law and the majesty of parliamentary procedures and the way in which we can in fact rely, as good, sturdy Anglo-Saxon successors to the glories of Westminster, upon the humanity and the wisdom of our legislators, the draftsmen who stand behind them and, of course, down the line, the judges who interpret the law and the bureaucrats and police who actually enforce it. This Government is happier with this kind of mythology that there is no need for substantial legislative protection of human rights-constitutional protection for rights-and parliamentary procedural protection for human rights of the kind contemplated here.

The reality is that this mythology about the Anglo-Saxon parliamentary and common law tradition is simply just that: Legislatures cannot be trusted to get everything right when it comes to the impact upon civil liberties of the bills that they pass. Questions of Executive and administrative convenience will constantly ensure that things do slip by which are manifestly unattractive unless they are very closely scrutinised by a committee of the kind that is contemplated here. It is simply bizarre for the Attorney to say, as he has said tonight and on previous occasions, that, among the various safety nets we can anticipate operating around the place, the government party committees of the day will have the opportunity to closely scrutinise the details of the Bills that they are in fact endorsing. That is like saying the lions of ancient Rome had the opportunity-as indeed they did-to scrutinise closely the Christians they were just about to eat. That is the kind of scrutiny that the government party committees can be expected to apply to legislation embodying interferences with civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the way in which the Opposition committees work.

—I spoke particularly in regard to the kind of committees that exist under the present Government. I have much greater confidence in the party committees which might be expected to operate under a Labor government. But there are occasions inevitably when, through inadvertence or pressure of time, considerations of this kind may in fact slip through the kind of dragnet that committees would otherwise be minded to apply. The question remains: What kind of committee is it most appropriate to set up? The original recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was in fact to establish not just a committee of this Senate but a joint committee of the Parliament with representation from both Houses and procedures to ensure that this committee was able to look at Bills before they were considered by either House of the Parliament, not just when they wended ultimately their weary way into this chamber. That is still a concept and proposition which I very much prefer.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been far too much chauvinism in the Parliament by members of both Houses about the prerogative of each vis-a-vis the other. Far too much nonsense has been talked by members of the House of Representatives about the folloy of joint committees. The Senate can play a useful role and fulfil a review function. That is something that I am very willing to acknowledge. Even more nonsense has been talked about the interference with the prerogatives and powers of the Senate by lending its participation to joint committees.

I think that a joint committee is the admirable solution for the kind of procedural innovation claimed here. I hope that we do not, in the course of adopting Senator Missen's modification of the proposal, lose sight of that ultimate objective. I certainly have not and the Opposition certainly has not. The proposal, however, is to be further modified, if Senator Hamer has his way, by the amendment which he has moved tonight, not even to establish at this stage a separate and distinct Senate committee but simply to allocate for the next six months the proposed functions to the existing Constiutional and Legal Affairs Committee. That is an amendment which, on balance, and after careful consideration, the Opposition is prepared to accept reasonably cheerfully. Not only has a deal been done to accept it, but also is it quite a rational proposal in the sense that it will allow a relatively new innovation to work itself out through our practice and procedures as well as some better assessment to be made than we are able to make at the moment about the kind of staff allocation that may be needed to support this function.

The motion moved by Senator Missen seems to have generated in recent days and weeks quite a remarkable amount of hyperbole-that is, exaggeration-which is in fact unmerited by the substance of the proposal before us. It is a significant proposal, as I readily acknowledge and as I would claim, but essentially it is quite a small procedural change that is before us now. It should be added-this is my final point-that the change is simply a logical corollary of the change which was introduced in 1931 in this chamber relating to delegated legislation. A procedure was introduced to ensure that the Parliament did not overlook invasions of liberty, perhaps inadvertently, by delegated legislation. All that is proposed here tonight is that this chamber, on behalf of the Parliament as a whole, now creates a procedure which will ensure that there are no invasions of liberty or excessive conferrals of Executive power by full scale legislation, again by way of inadvertence. The only occasion for concern that the Parliament or the nation should have about the passage of Senator Missen's motion tonight is the way in which the Government seems to be losing in its opposition to this motion whatever remains of its sense of perspective. For all those reasons, I indicate, as Senator Tate has before me, that the Opposition will support both Senator Missen's motion to establish this committee and also Senator Hamer's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate briefly that I support what my colleague, Senator Missen, has proposed. At the outset, I wish to respond to a remark made by my colleague on the other side of the chamber. He said that this chamber is made up of Anglo-Saxons. I make it quite clear that it is not made up entirely of Anglo-Saxons any more than it is made up of WASPs, that is white Anglo-Saxon protestants. There are other people in the chamber. I make the point very clear. What my colleague, Senator Missen, is endeavouring to do in proposing this motion is nothing, in my opinion, of which the Government or any member of this chamber should be afraid. The proposed committee would be very little more than our Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The proposed committee would be examining legislation in minute detail and reporting back to the Senate. The Senate could then look at the points that have been raised. That system could operate in the same manner as the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances operates. In that Committee we have counsel who examines the regulation or ordinance before the Committee and points out those parts of it that infringe civil liberties and the individual rights of people. The Committee looks at the points raised and the Chairman of the Committee reports to honourable senators in this chanber. Honourable senators collectively can then look at those points and, if they think the regulation or ordinance concerned is wrong, they can disallow it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen is not seeking to go even that far in his proposal to set up a standing committee for the scrutiny of Bills. All he is proposing is that such a committee should look at legislation, should examine it in minute detail and should report back to the Senate on it. The Senate would then have the power to decide whether the points raised by the committee should be looked at more closely in the Senate.

I believe that what my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has said tonight has no bearing on what my colleague Senator Missen proposes in setting up such a committee. I think the Government should welcome such a proposal. With such a committee the Government would know that legislation introduced into this Parliament could be examined by that committee. When the chairman of the committee reported to the Senate the Senate could go through the bad points in the legislation. The Government would then have the opportunity of saying: Okay; the committee has looked at the legislation and the Senate has looked at it. We should change it to make it a good piece of legislation'.

For those reasons, I support the proposal of my colleague Senator Missen. I believe that the amendment moved by another of my colleagues, Senator Hamer, could provide a means whereby legislation could be examined promptly by a committee; namely, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. If, after that Committee has had an opportunity to look at legislation and to report to the Senate on it, such a system is proved worthwhile, we could set up what my colleague Senator Missen really wants; namely, a permanent standing committee to examine legislation that comes to this Senate. However, in the short term, perhaps Senator Hamer's proposal is the best course of action for us to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We already have 34 Senate committees and I am opposed to having 35 committees. I do not believe that the case that has been put by fewer than half a dozen honourable senators for setting up this thirty-fifth committee has been persuasive. I believe that if we have so many committees that the activity and attention of honourable senators are taken away from the chamber we will have even less-
—It is to get us away from you.

—That may well be. If we do that the debate in this chamber will be of less value. In recent years the incidence of a lack of full attendance in the Senate has increased, except for very few periods during a division or when Question Time is in progress. Even then, towards the end of Question Time, some honourable senators leave the chamber. I do not believe that the Senate can sustain 35 committees. The committee proposed by Senator Missen, whilst it would have the best of intentions, does not need to be set up. Individual senators are continuously vigilant about civil rights and about any possible invasion of individual liberty. A special committee does not need to be set up to do that work. If we over-topple the Senate with committees we will put in jeopardy the excellence of the committee structure, particularly as it was developed in the late 1960s. At the moment we have several select committees as well as the standing committees, joint committees and Estimates committees. It is difficult to fill the places on those committees. At the moment one select committee is not meeting, is not going about its business, because there is a lack of senators.

SPEECH.PARA: If we put the committee system in disrepute by having too many committees, we will put in jeopardy one of the very real strengths of the Senate. I do not believe it has been established that we need a thirty-fifth committee. If we are to have a committee to look at the invasion of civil liberties of individual Australians, why not have three or four other committees. What about a committee to look at the impact of any legislation on families in Australia? Let us have a family impact statements committee of the Senate. Alternatively, let us look at the efficiency of operation of some programs. Why can we not have some honourble senators meeting to look at what a Bill proposes, be it a new program or a strengthening of a program? Such a committee could look at the efficiency of legislation to see whether there was any duplication in it and to make sure that inefficiencies and duplication were erased from it.

Why do we not have another committee to look at whether or not there are particular State advantages subtly involved in the wording of any particular legislation? This is a States House. Let the Senate have another committee to try to eliminate any particular State advantage which may need to be brought to the attention of honourable senators so that we can be all the more alert. Let us have another committee which maximises individual citizens' participation in any program which legislation sets forth. Many honourable senators believe that individual Australians ought to be involed in public affairs. Any program that is set up ought to consider how we can involve more people, rather than have elitists sitting behind closed doors and forming little bureaucracies remote from the people. Let us have a committee to see how we can maximise public participation in decisions which the Senate makes. A long list of various values which honourable senators have could be examined against all of the legisltion which passes through the Senate to see whether those values are vigilantly being maintained by that legislation. Whilst I am not arguing against the admirable intention of such a committee as the one proposed, I believe there are other contenders of just as much importance. Why should we add unnecessarily to the paraphernalia and bureaucracy with which honourable senators are increasingly becoming involved?

I do not see in the Senate any lack of attention by honourable senators to the question of civil liberties. How have we managed in the Senate for 81 years without such a committee? Why is it that after 81 years all of a sudden we have to bring into being this new committee? I believe the great majority of Government senators see this as just another step that may delay and complicate the procedures for decision within this place. If we bring the excellent committee system of the Senate into disrepute by overburdening it, we will be dong the Senate a great disservice. I do not support the proposal for the committee and I do not support Senator Hamer's amendment that it be given, as an overburdening, to one of our standing committees. Therefore, I urge honourable senators not to vote with those few honourable senators who have proposed this committee, but to vote with the majority of Government senators who are opposed to it and with the majority of silent members of the Senate who, I believe, are also not persuaded that it should be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of the fact that we have only six minutes until the Senate is due to adjourn. It is not my intention to talk this motion out; I think we should debate it this evening. Nevertheless, I take the opportunity to speak briefly because I think the position of Government senators has been misrepresented this evening. This is not a question for the Government or for the Opposition. It is a question for the Senate. If one were to pursue the argument just put to the Senate, I think we would have an excellent argument for abolishing the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. We had put to us the general principle that we ought to have a very particular type of scrutiny of Bills which relates to the rights, liberties and obligations of government and of our position in the Senate. It is incumbent on all honourable senators when they vote on this motion and on the amendment to bear in mind that they are first and foremost parliamentarians and only secondly representatives of parties or, indeed, of States.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an argument to be put for all sorts of committees of the Senate. We could have commitees that scrutinise from the point of view of the States and so on. If honourable senators want to move a motion to that effect, if they think it is of equal significance to this one, they have an equal right to do so. I will vote for this motion because I think it is important in a parliamentary sense that we have a standing committee that is established which can oversight legislation in the way that is proposed for this standing committee in Senator Missen's motion. I am not entirely pursuaded that we need to delay in the way that Senator Hamer's amendment would require. But there are those who have been involved in the issue for some time; I understand that Senator Missen is not unhappy with the amendment so I will go along with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite happy.

—Senator Missen indicates that he is quite happy. Apparently he feels that the thrust of his motion would not be deferred by the amendment. Under those circumstances I will support the amendment. I will support it on the grounds that it will get the committee set up, one hopes, eventually. That is the important issue. I vote tonight not as a Government senator, not as a Liberal senator, not as a Queensland senator; but as a member of the Australian Parliament who believes that the Senate committee system has something objective to offer regardless of party and origin of constituency. I rise only to indicate that I do not believe it is a vote between parties, Government and Opposition or Opposition and a few Government senators; it is a vote that will be recorded against people's opinion of the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply very briefly. I thank my colleagues who have spoken in support of this motion. I think that they have replied quite substantially to the argument by the Government. Two matters were raised by the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, that do call for slight reply. He argued that it would be invidious to establish this committee and that it should be the responsibility of a number of honourable senators, or all honourable senators, actually to do the scrutiny work. Of course, it is the obligation of all honourable senators to do that. The facts that I have produced, the investigation which was undertaken in 1980 and our experience have shown that, unfortunately, quite a lot of it has not been done. We only have to be honest with ourselves to admit that. This committee is not designed to take away the responsibility or to lessen the responsibility of senators, but it is designed to arm them with information, to have a counsel and a committee that will look into these matters and draw them to the attention of honourable senators. As I see myself now as being the chairman of this committee-if the motion is carried-in my double capacity, I assure the Senate that where there is a Bill which is of concern to another standing committee we would draw its attention to what seem to be defects, just as the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances does to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory when matters relate to that committee. Of course there will be that communication and no lessening of the obligation of other members.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the second point. A new argument has been put forward tonight that it is difficult to isolate one's judgment from a Bill as a whole and its social purpose; if we have this sort of committee which is being given this type of recommendation then the committee might have too much influence and decisions might be made on different questions. This is the very problem that exists at the moment. Often these minor or smaller points are not seen because of the overwhelming debate on other matters. That problem will be overcome. I do not take it further. This is part of the task which the Senate ought to do. I believe that the motion has the support of most honourable senators. I trust Senator Hamer's amendment, which I think is a sensible and practical one, and the motion, as amended, will be carried.

That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Hamer's amendment) be inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to outline some of the less satisfactory aspects of the television service to some remote areas in Queensland which are now receiving television for the first time. The areas to which I shall refer are those receiving television programs by way of the Intelsat IV international communications satellite. Programs are beamed to this satellite from two places in Australia-from Carnarvon in Western Australia and from Moree in New South Wales. Three States, South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland, and the Northern Territory receive television services through the Moree station. These television programs originate in Sydney. A land link takes the programs from Sydney's Australian Broadcasting Commission studios to Moree. This means that Sydney programs are beamed to the Northern Territory and to States which have nothing in common with Sydney. Some people might say: 'What is wrong with that? A TV program is a TV program'.

SPEECH.PARA: I will outline some of the things that are wrong with it so far as Queensland is concerned. Firstly, there is a time difference of one hour when New South Wales fiddles with the time in summer, as is the case now. Therefore, programs are one hour ahead of time when they are shown in Queensland if they originate in Sydney. In addition to this, sports programs which are seen by people who receive television in this way have a New South Wales bias. Whilst this might not necessarily be something that one should be terribly concerned about, people in Queensland would much rather see Queensland programs, such as a rugby league game from Brisbane rather than a rugby league game from Sydney. In addition to this a number of people who are receiving these programs complain to me that they cannot receive race results as other people in Queensland can. People in one particular place-I imagine there are more-have difficulty receiving radio programs and therefore they cannot receive the race results they would like. Scarcely anything is said about the main Queensland race meetings on programs that originate in Sydney. I believe that Sydney gives the race results for the daily treble in Brisbane but that is about all. In addition to this one must think of news broadcasts. First of all they are at a different time when we have summer time in New South Wales. Also there is a New South Wales bias towards news programs that people receive, say, in northern Queensland. People in northern Queensland tell me that they are not particularly interested in the regional news that comes on before the main news because the regional news comes from northern New South Wales.

If the centres served by satellite in Queensland were fewer than they were in New South Wales, there might be some justification for Queensland having to receive the New South Wales program. But I will outline how many remote areas are being served in the various States by the satellite. In New South Wales there are 7 centres, in Queensland 17, in South Australia 4, and in the Northern Territory 4. I did not mention Western Australia because all Western Australian programs originate in that State, where there are 19 areas. I will go back to the New South Wales programs that originate in Sydney. The Queensland centres that receive television via the satellite are far greater than they are in New South Wales. In fact they are greater than the centres in New South Wales, South Australia and the Northern Territory combined. Therefore I ask these questions: Why should the centres in Queensland have to receive New South Wales programs? Why not have a link from Brisbane to Moree rather than a link from Sydney to Moree? I ask these questions on behalf of the suffering Queensland viewers: Is it possible to service Moree with a line from Brisbane? If not why is it not possible? Is it possible for Moree to send two signals, a New South Wales signal and a Queensland signal, to the satellite? I do not know whether this is technically possible. It may or may not be possible to beam them down separately. If Queensland cannot be adequately serviced, is it possible to build a further communications station to beam Queensland programs to a satellite and then beam them down to Queensland viewers?

I realise that these are probably fairly technical questions which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) may not be be able to answer tonight. If he is not able to do so, I would be pleased if he would find the answers so that I can pass them on to the people in Queensland who would like to see some local programs, programs that originate in Queensland. Even though some of them are far distant from Brisbane they would be satisfied if they could have some programs that originate in Brisbane because at least they would be able to receive news services from there and sports results that pertain to Queensland and their television service would become much richer than it is at the moment. I would be pleased if the Minister were able to give me some information and perhaps give me some further information when officers from the Department are able to provide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston raised the question of really a more appropriate kind of programming for some of the remote communities in Queensland which are dependent upon Intelstat for their television reception. A considerable advance has been given by the introduction of the Intelsat IV program and it has meant that many of these remote communities now have a television reception which they previously did not have. Senator Colston is correct that for the television viewers in Queensland, South Australia, the Northern Territory and New South Wales the programs are produced in Sydney and carried by conventional linkage to Moree and beamed from there to the satellite and back to the earth receiving stations. I am informed, however, that the answer which the honourable senator is seeking may in fact come to pass.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that what is called by the Department of Communications the Eastern States Program, to distinguish it from the program in Western Australia to which Senator Colston referred, will eventually originate not from Sydney but from the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Brisbane when Telecom Australia can provide a terrestrial circuit between Brisbane and Moree. So the matter referred to in the question asked by Senator Colston is in fact intended to take place by the Department of Communications under the Remote Area Television Service. Of course, the initial program is not the final product. It represents an initial step; perhaps a trade-off. Senator Colston is quite correct. People in Quilpie, perhaps, who are receiving Moree local news may feel it has no relevance to them, but it is still television reception which they did not have previously. It is an advance and of benefit to them. The fact that it is intended that eventually there should be a link from Brisbane to Moree, exactly as Senator Colston asked, is something which should be of some interest to him. The system is one which is evolving and the present situation is not one that will last.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have a time frame?

—I do not have a time frame but I have been told-and I just repeat the words-'when Telecom can provide a terrestrial circuit between Brisbane and Moree'. That at least takes up the point that concerns Senator Colston. I recall having been at Bamaga not so long ago. Senator Colston may know that there is a horse called Prince Ruling, a very good race horse, owned by the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs. It was racing that day somewhere in Sydney. We discovered to our horror that no matter how we worked on the local radios-I was not so concerned but my colleague was-and no matter how we looked to our colleagues and friends in Bamaga for help, there was no way he could hear Prince Ruling race in Sydney. Of course what made it even sadder was that the horse, a very good horse, won that race quite easily. So he was certainly well aware of the need for remote area reception. The Government is aware of it. The program is coming into place. The initial steps have been taken and eventually there will be a link between Brisbane and Mooree, as Senator Colston suggests.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
